talk.start.para: - My question is directed to the Minister for Transport. I direct his attention to a booklet on the Trans-Australia Railway in which appears a photograph of the Commonwealth Railways Provisions Store at Port Augusta. I ask the Minister whether this store is conducted by the Commonwealth Railways Department or is it let to private enterprise? Will he say whether the Commonwealth Government is engaged in the grocery business in connexion with the Trans-Australia Railways?

- For many years, as a traveller on the Trans-Australia line, I have known of the existence of this store at Port Augusta, It has been there as long as I can remember, and it was established for the purpose of catering for the needs of employees of the Commonwealth Railways who were working at isolated points on the Trans-Australia line. Senator Henty may not be aware that there are no stores at those places.
- That store has done a wonderful job.

- lt is still doing a wonderful job. Its operations extend to other government employees, such as teachers and members of the police force, but private residents in the town of Port Augusta are not allowed to trade at that store. It is a government concern which was established as a natural development of the Commonwealth Trans-Australia railway to cater primarily for the needs of the employees on that line who have not the amenities available to other people living in the town.
- I ask the Minister for Transport whether, in view of the fact that many West Australian people are finding great difficulty in arranging transport to

question.para: Melbourne to attend the Olympic Games, the Minister will consider running additional trains to enable patrons to attend this important event.

talk.start.para: - Quite recently, an additional train was put into service on the Trans-Australia line, thus increasing the service to four a week. There is provision for a further train to be put on in October. I have not the exact details, as to when it will come into service, but my impression is it will be in time to cater for both the Olympic Games and the Christmas traffic.

- I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Civil Aviation. If he is not in a position to provide the answer to-day, will he secure information as to when the amenities, such as lounges, waiting rooms and other improvements, at the West Beach airport in South Australia will be completed, in order that the long-suffering public will be at least relieved of the inconvenience that they now endure?
- I will refer the question to my colleague, the Minister for Civil Aviation, and let the honorable senator have the information as soon as I can.

- Is the Minister representing the Minister for Supply aware that heavy stock losses in the north-west of Western Australia are said to be due, directly or indirectly, to the Monte Bello atomic explosions? Is he aware that droving delays in bringing cattle from the interior through a tick-infested area to be transhipped to Perth, have led to serious stock shortages and deaths? If this is so will the Australian Government consider whether it or the British Government will pay some compensation to the owners for the loss of cattle in such circumstances?

- Personally, I have not heard of the losses the honorable senator has mentioned; but if what she says is true, it is a very serious matter. I shall bring to the notice of the Minister for Supply the details of the question and obtain a considered reply for her as early as possible.

- My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Civil Aviation. I preface it by stating that yesterday when I and other members of the Parliament were travelling to Canberra in a Viscount aeroplane which left Adelaide at approximately 7 a.m. we noticed on our port side another aeroplane which seemed to us to be flying at the same altitude, ls there any provision under the regulations of the Department of Civil Aviation that all aeroplanes flying on approximately the same route or in the same direction - I do not know whether this other aeroplane we noticed was flying on exactly the same route, or even whether it was going to the same destination - shall not fly at exactly the same height?

- My understanding of the position is as Senator Hannaford has described it - that aeroplanes fly at different levels when in proximity one to the other. I have no knowledge, of course, of the particular circumstances to which he has referred. I shall refer the question to my colleague and get a reply for the honorable senator.

- In view of the great economies that can be effected by the use of diesel-electric locomotives, which are estimated to be 30 per cent, cheaper to operate than steam locomotives, will the Minister for Shipping and Transport state whether there is in existence any overall Commonwealth plan to assist the States in financing conversion to these diesel units. This could make a most valuable contribution to lowering freight charges, and so help to reduce production and distributions costs, which are such a big element in the inflationary spiral that exists in Australia to-day.
- The conduct of State railway systems, and the purchase and replacement of plant for those systems is, of course, quite obviously a function of the State authorities concerned.
- I asked whether the Commonwealth had any plan to help them.

- The Commonwealth has not been asked by any of the State railway authorities to purchase any equipment on their behalf. T emphasize that such a request could only be viewed in the light of the responsibilities of the State governments concerned. There is no doubt, as Senator O'Byrne has said, that dieselization is proving to be a boon to all systems, and progressively increasing steps have been taken by the various railway systems to replace their steam locomotives with diesel power.

- As the Commonwealth is vitally interested in the provision of suitable transport for persons who wish to visit Canberra, will the Minister for Shipping and Transport ascertain from the New South Wales Department of Railways why rail services to Canberra are being curtailed. Will the Minister also endeavour to assist the State railways to keep trains running between Canberra and the capital cities of Melbourne and Sydney?
- I shall have the position examined. I am not sure whether I correctly interpreted the honorable senator's question. Did he refer to the operation of trains within the Australian Capital Territory?
- Yes.
- I shall have the position examined and furnish the honorable senator with particulars of the service now provided by the Commonwealth Railways.

- The question that I direct to the Minister for Shipping and Transport is supplementary to that asked by Senator Sheehan. Will the Minister consider the possibility of commencing the rail service for persons travelling from Canberra to Melbourne at Yass, and providing a road transport link between Canberra and Yass? I believe that by so doing the travelling time between Canberra and Melbourne could be cut by approximately five hours.
- I shall have a look at the proposal.

- I direct a question to the Minister representing the Postmaster-General. Is the Postmaster-General aware that there is a possibility that outside labour will be brought in to assist in the sorting of mails in Tasmania? Is he aware that if such labour is used it will be regarded most unfavorably by members of the Postal Workers Union? Does he not think that this would aggravate the present situation; and will he take steps to prevent the engagement of such casual labour in view of the present situation?
- I shall put the matter before the Postmaster-General and ask him if he will give me a report on the questions submitted by the honorable senator.

- I direct a question to you, Mr. President. It concerns a wooden building that is being constructed on the roof of Parliament House. Can you tell the Senate who is responsible for this particularly ugly building being put on the roof of Parliament House where the general public may see it? Why is it necessary? Has its construction and design been approved by any competent authority? Has the matter been brought to your notice?
- I shall look into the matter and let the honorable senator have a reply at a later date.

speech.para: Before speaking on the subject-matter of the Customs Tariff Bill (No. 2) 1956, I should like to advise honorable senators that this is the first of a series of six tariff bills which the Senate will be asked to consider. In each case, the bill is designed to give effect to tariff alterations which were introduced by resolutions in another place some time ago. As honorable senators are aware, immediately following the introduction of tariff resolutions, duties are collected in accordance with the alterations proposed, and therefore the amendments contained in the bills are actually in operation, but the passing of the bills is necessary to give statutory effect to those amendments.

The bill now before honorable senators covers proposed amendments to the Customs Tariff 1933-1956. In the main, these amendments are consequent upon adoption by the Government of recommendations made by the Tariff Board. Other proposed amendments have as their objective the clarification of existing tariff items or to extend, in some instances, the scope of existing concessional items.

As will be apparent from the " Summary of Alterations " which I have had prepared for the information of honorable senators, the proposed amendments cover a comprehensive cross-section of consumer goods and aids to production which are being commercially produced in Australia. Of the principal commodities in respect of which the Tariff Board has recommended that tariff assistance be accorded, I mention the following: -

Upholstery moquettes, ribbons and galloons, tyre cord and tyre cord fabric, and cotton canvas and duck piece goods;
Aluminium angles, bars, rods, pipes, wire, plates, sheets and strip;
Fuel injection equipment for compression ignition engines;

Covered cable and wire as used in electrical undertakings;
Forged table knives, domestic aluminiumware. incandescent lamps and lanterns, domestic heat storage cooking stoves and ranges and safety pins;
Hacksaw blades, woodworking chisels, car- penters' braces and plumbers' vises;

speech.para: Various chemical products such as -

quote.para: Naphthalene, cresylic acid, phenol, formaldehyde, magnesium sulphate, methyl chloride, and various phosphorus derivatives;
Vitreous enamels;
Wristlet watch cases:
Goloshes, sand shoes, boots and shoes;
Greaseproof wrapping paper, vegetable parchment paper, and filter paper;
Motor vehicle front axle assemblies;
Synthetic resins;
Vacuum cleaners; and
Continuous filament acetate rayon yarn.

speech.para: Decreased duties, based on Tariff Board recommendations, are proposed in respect of the following commodities: -

quote.para: Filament lamps of the types ordinarily used in motor vehicles for lighting purposes;
Commercial type heat storage cooking stoves and ranges;

I do not propose at this stage to take up any more of the Senate's time in traversing the circumstances associated with the numerous variations set out in the bill. If, however, honorable senators desire to be more fully informed in relation to any individual items, I shall endeavour to enlighten them in that direction when the items come up for consideration. Honorable senators will note that this bill deals with only one item of the Excise Tariff 1921-1956. The amendment proposed is of a concessional nature, and is designed to exempt from the payment of excise duty spirits used for scientific and educational purposes by approved technical colleges and other educational institutions. For many years spirits used in universities for scientific purposes have been delivered free of excise duty, but in the case of technical colleges, agricultural colleges, mining schools, forestry schools, and the like, any spirits used by them attracted a duty of 25s. a proof gallon. Individually the quantity of spirits used by these colleges and schools is small, but as virtually all those institutions come within the jurisdiction of the education departments of the various States, it was considered that the Commonwealth should not add to the already substantial expenditure incurred by the States in their upkeep by collecting an excise duty on spirits for educational and research purposes. I am confident that honorable senators will readily acknowledge the valuable contribution being made in the fields of education and research by colleges and schools such as I have mentioned, and will support the passage of this bill.

speech.para: This bill is complementary to the trade agreement concluded last year between Australia and the Federation of Rhodesia and Nyasaland and is designed to give effect to the tariff concessions which Australia has undertaken to accord to certain goods which are produced or manufactured in the Federation. Honorable senators will recall that the text of the trade agreement was tabled in this chamber in October last. In the circumstances, I feel that it is unnecessary for me to deal in detail with the various features of that agreement.

The tariff concessions which are embodied in this bill relate to fruit juices, unmanufactured tobacco, beeswax, tung oil, citrus oils, crude asbestos and chrome ore. In each case, other than unmanufactured tobacco, the bill provides that the goods shall be dutiable at the rate in force under the British preferential tariff. On unmanufactured tobacco the rate of duty proposed is 9d. per lb. less than the British preferential tariff. Apart from tung oil, which is already free of duty from all sources, the concessions proposed have been in operation for a number of years in respect of one or other of the territories of the federation. The effect of the bill is therefore merely to extend the preferential treatment on the goods concerned to the federation as a whole.

speech.para: The bill now before honorable senators proposes to implement, insofar as variations to the Customs Tariff schedule are concerned, those tariff concessions undertaken by Australia during the negotiations at Geneva earlier this year under the auspices of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. The proposed amendments in this bill do not implement all the tariff concessions granted by. Australia at Geneva. For example, Australia accorded various primage concessions, the benefit of certain intermediate tariff rates of duty and the binding of various margins of preference to certain countries. Other action has, however, been taken to give effect to these changes.

The bill also proposes to give effect to decisions taken by the Government to adopt certain recommendations made by the Tariff Board in regard to the protective needs of various industries to which I will refer at a later stage. I should, however, make it quite clear to honorable senators that these particular amendments are not not associated in any way with those arising from the General Agreement on Tariff and Trade negotiations at Geneva. The " Memorandum of Alterations " which has already been circulated to honorable senators sets out in detail the extent of the tariff and primage variations accorded by Australia at Geneva. It also sets out the extent of the tariff changes based on Tariff Board recommendations. At the Geneva negotiations Australia exchanged concessions with Germany, the United States of America, and Austria. As was anticipated when Australia decided to take part in the 1956 conference, the scope for negotiation was not comparable with that of previous occasions.
Australia's export trade should, however, benefit from the following concessions: -
Germany: Fresh apples, meat extracts, frozen rabbits, lead ore, and eucalyptus tanning extracts;
United States of America: Eucalyptus tanning extracts, frozen rabbits, eucalyptus oil, arid catgut;
Austria: Honey, meat extract, and eucalyptus tanning extracts.
Honorable senators will, of course, be aware that it is a principle of the General

Agreement on Tariffs and Trade that a concession granted by any contracting party also applies to all other members. Apart from the direct concessions, Australian export trade will, therefore, benefit from the negotiations concluded between other contracting parties at Geneva. Tariff and primage concessions given by Australia, in broad terms, involve -
Duty reductions on -
Textile bleaching and dyeing machinery; battery eliminating devices and choke coils for wireless receivers; spectacle frames; and beer.
Binding of the duties at existing most favoured nation level on -
Embroideries in the piece, gold leaf, microscopes, and rubber, canvas, and composition belting (other than conveyor belting).
Removal of primage duty on -

Gold leaf; various mining and metal lurgical machinery; weighing machines; various road-making machinery; textile bleaching and dyeing machines; machines and machinery not elsewhere included; battery eliminating devices and chokes for wireless receivers; various gas appliances; rubber, canvas and composition belting - other than conveyor belting; various fancy boxes; magic lanterns and mounted lenses and camera accessories.

From Australia's point of view the outcome of these negotiations is reasonably balanced. The negotiations cannot, of themselves, be regarded as of major significance to our export trade, but they will, nevertheless, improve the market prospects for a number of our primary products. Honorable senators will readily appreciate that the state of Australia's balance of payments is now such that the Government cannot overlook any means of expanding exports or of raising the returns from exports. The concessions accorded by Australia are not likely to have any adverse effect on local industries which are conducted on an economic and efficient basis.

The proposed tariff variations associated with Tariff Board recommendations, to which I referred earlier, relate to electrically-operated hand tools covered by tariff items 176 (u)(2) and 176 (u)(3), various dry colours, dyes and pigments covered by items 231 (a) and 231 (e)(2), synthetic oils and preparations containing synthetic resins covered by item 232 (e) and synthetic resins used in the paint industry formerly included in item 232 (e), but now covered by item 369 (c).

As will be seen from Part B of the memorandum already in the hands of honorable senators, some increases in the duties on these goods are proposed, and on the remainder the duties either remain unchanged or have been reduced. These variations give full effect to Tariff Board recommendations. I commend the bill to honorable senators.

debate.para: Debate resumed from 4th September (vide page 92), on motion by Senator Marriott -

That, in the opinion of the Senate, the present practice of broadcasting the proceedings of the Commonwealth Parliament should either cease oi be varied to provide for the broadcasting of portions only of those proceedings, such as question time in both Houses and important speeches in either House; and that this resolution be forwarded for the consideration of the Government.

talk.start.para: . - In continuing my remarks on the motion moved by Senator Marriott, I should like to state emphatically that I favour the abolition of the broadcasting of parliamentary proceedings of both Houses of the Parliament. As I support that portion of the motion, automatically I am not in favour of a portion only of parliamentary proceedings, such as question time and important speeches, being broadcast. I repeat that after studying procedure in this chamber and in another place I have come to the conclusion that very often questions are not asked primarily to elicit information. We have the privilege of asking questions, with or without notice; and the fundamental principle behind that privilege is that honorable senators can elicit information that is important to the community.

speech.para: A study of this matter leads me to the conclusion that the greater proportion of questions asked in this chamber and in another place are designed not to elicit information but to disseminate subtle propaganda. Whether this motion is carried or not, I greatly favour, as far as the Senate is concerned, questions being placed on the notice-paper. Strangely enough, I am not a great advocate of questions being asked without notice in this chamber. The questions asked are directed to the various departments. As there are 22 Ministers of whom only five are in this chamber, it is a reasonable assumption that, on the average, only five out of 22 questions asked without notice can be answered directly in this chamber. Because of that fact alone I should much prefer to see questions placed on the notice-paper so that the responsible Minister could give the chamber a considered reply. I do not think it is a reflection on any Minister as the representative in this chamber of a Minister in another place to have to reply, " I shall refer that to my colleague, and I ask the honorable senator to place his question on the notice-paper". Therefore, it would be much better if all questions were put on the notice-paper. For that reason and various others which I shall not emphasize again, I could not agree that questions only should be broadcast.

When we consider whether certain selected subjects only should be broadcast we open up a very wide field. Who is to be the arbitrator, judge or umpire to decide what particular speeches on what subjects should be broadcast? Therefore, I come back to my first submission, that in existing circumstances parliamentary debates in this chamber and in another place should not be broadcast. Why do I say that?

talk.start.para: - I have no idea.

- The honorable senator says he has no idea. I can give honorable senators one or two reasons why I have reached this conclusion. First of all, supporters of the continuation of broadcasting have failed, at least to my way of thinking, to produce any tangible argument to show that broadcasting has improved the political knowledge, or even increased the political interest, of the great majority of radio listeners in Australia. Yet, that was the original intention of broadcasting parliamentary proceedings.
- Does not the honorable senator think that people are better informed now?

- All 1 am going to say is that perhaps 8 per cent, of the people are better informed; but that 8 per cent, represents the hard core of listeners to political broadcasts. Do not let any one deceive himself by thinking that more than 8 per cent, of radio listeners listen to parliamentary broadcasts. The figures I cited previously can be verified; they come from a very sound authority. They were tabulated when broadcasting was a novelty. Since then, it is reasonable to assume that the number of people who listen to the broadcasting of parliamentary proceedings has decreased. Senator Hannaford asked by interjection whether the people's knowledge of parliamentary affairs had not been improved by the broadcasting of parliamentary proceedings. It has been my experience that the 8 per cent, of listeners - the hard core that I mentioned earlier - belong to one or other of the great political parties. They comprise men and women who, in normal circumstances, would scan the daily newspapers or read " Hansard " in order to keep abreast of political matters. Those avenues of information are still available to such people. But that 8 per cent, of listeners could not, from such other channels of information, realize the showmanship that is engaged in during certain of the parliamentary proceedings. I am fortified in this opinion by the fact that every previous speaker who has opposed Senator Marriott's motion has said that the broadcasting of parliamentary proceedings is unreal. I remind honorable senators that these are not my words, but the words of previous speakers, who have said that we give to the public an unreal impression because only certain selected subjects are debated when the proceedings are being broadcast. Last night, the Leader of the Opposition (Senator McKenna), who engages in debate with a great deal of vigour, said that debates on certain subjects are arranged to take place when the proceedings are being broadcast. Every speaker who has supported the continuation of parliamentary broadcasts has agreed with Senator Marriott's opinion that the microphone rules the Parliament. As T. said earlier, all previous speakers who have supported the motion have stated that the usual procedure has been altered to enable particular matters to be debated when we are on the air. As we have bien told, the reason for this practice is to gain the public ear. That is a very soft impeachment that parliamentary broadcasts present an unreal picture of the proceedings in both houses of the Parliament.

speech.para: In my opinion, second-reading speeches, although valuable, are not half as valuable as the discussions that take place during the committee stage of bills. At that stage, in the cut and thrust of debate, clauses, sentences, phrases and even single words are debated. To my way of thinking, the committee stage is of the very essence of parliamentary debating, and good legislating. Let us consider the views of the public in this connexion. The majority of those who listen to parliamentary broadcasts say that the committee stage of the proceedings is not suitable for broadcasting. Neither do they consider that divisions should be broadcast. They favour the elimination of the broadcasting of these proceedings. But, if the public is to be fully informed, I consider that the proceedings in committee should be broadcast.

I heard some very interesting remarks last night about what should be done in the broadcasting time occupied by divisions. I might say that I did not, by any means, agree with some of the remarks. Last night, also, a certain honorable senator gave us a very interesting talk about what might go over the air. I could relate many interesting things that have occurred in this chamber that I should not like broadcast. Last night, we had an opportunity to observe the attitude of one particular senator towards the suggestion that the Senate should bc abolished. 1 recall two very admirable men stating on the hustings that they favoured the abolition of the Senate. Eventually they were elected to the Senate, and held high office in this chamber. When the first man made his maiden speech, he did not say one word about the abolition of the Senate. The second man apparently took the view that, as his colleague had said nothing on that subject, he should express himself as being in favour of the abolition of the Senate. While he was engaged fervently and theatrically in so doing, his friend pulled his coat and said, " Sit down, for goodness sake. You are in the Senate now ". Thereupon, the honorable senator sat down without completing his remarks about the abolition of the Senate.

talk.start.para: - He threw overboard his principles.
- I am not discussing what he threw overboard; I am merely saying that he proceeded no further concerning the abolition of the Senate.
- There are still a few of use who think that it should be abolished.
- But not you!
- Yes, I am one of those who do.

- Many people who are interested in broadcasting as a whole contend that the broadcasting of parliamentary proceedings interferes seriously with advertised programmes. The views of the 92 per cent, of listeners who do not usually listen to parliamentary broadcasts should be considered. One of their chief grounds of complaint is, that owing to the uncertain times and days of sittings of the Parliament, there are many occasions on which ordinary programmes have to be either cancelled or altered. I could cite the number of complaints that are received by the Australian Broadcasting Commission when advertised programmes are cancelled because of parliamentary broadcasts. As we all know, when we attend parliamentary sittings we do not know their probable duration. I do not know whether any timetable for debates is arranged. Even the Government itself has no idea how long debates will last, and if it does know when a sessional period will terminate, it successfully keeps that information to itself. Certainly, private members of this chamber do not know how long sessional periods will last. Of course, that is not the fault of the broadcasting. I should not like any honorable senator to think that 1 am blaming broadcasting for that state of affairs. What I am saying is, that it would greatly assist the people in charge of broadcasting if they knew that the sittings would end on a certain day. lt would assist materially if we could have definite information as to when Parliament will be sitting and for exactly how long it will be sitting. I remind the Senate that the Australian Broadcasting Commission in particular has to arrange its programmes weeks and sometimes months ahead. Every time there is a cancellation or alteration of a programme that has been arranged for transmission over the Australian Broadcasting Commission network, a great deal of expenditure and work is incurred in making adjustments. The public certainly objects strongly to any alteration to an advertised programme. I have pointed out already that the Australian Broadcasting Commission has brought to Australia some of the leading artists of the world. I might mention also that earlier this year it was believed that the parliamentary session would end on 31st May. Acting on that belief, the Australian Broadcasting Commission arranged for one of the world's leading pianists to broadcast on 19th June. That orchestralconcert which included performances by this pianist was advertised to be broadcast on 19th June, but, because Parliament sat longer than was expected, it had to be cancelled. At other times, operas which have been arranged for weeks in advance have had to be cancelled hurriedly, often causing a great deal of inconvenience to the listening public.

speech.para: Any cancellation or alteration must cause inconvenience. Even if a particular item is transferred to another network, it means that a part of the programme on that other network has to be cancelled. Again, in many instances, arrangements have been made weeks ahead for broadcasting these programmes throughout the whole of Australia over land lines which have been booked from the Postmaster-General's Department. Any cancellation or alteration of the programme causes great inconvenience and disruption in that department. No matter from what angle we examine the question, it is safe to say that if we abolished the broadcasting of parliamentary proceedings we would eliminate a great potential cause of inconvenience and cost resulting from changes in advertised programmes.

Another point is that programmes are often recorded before the actual date of broadcast. What is more, they are usually paid for long before they go over the air. It may not be possible to broadcast any programme that is cancelled for many weeks after the original advertised date. This means that valuable tape is taken up in holding the item awaiting broadcast; and there is an acute shortage of recording tape in Australia. Another important point is that an item that might have had a tremendous amount of importance and interest at the particular date at which it was originally intended to be broadcast loses that value very often if broadcast at any other time. In conclusion, I reiterate that I support Senator Marriott's motion. As I favour the abolition of broadcasting of parliamentary proceedings, I do not support the broadcasting of proceedings either at question time or even when important speeches are being delivered. It is my firm belief that before parliamentary proceedings were broadcast the standard of debate in this chamber was higher than it is today. For those reasons, I support the complete abolition of the broadcasting of parliamentary proceedings.

talk.start.para: . - Let me make my position clear at the outset. I am not afraid of anything that I say in this chamber being broadcast to the public of Australia. Therefore, I oppose the motion. It is my belief that any honorable senator, or any member of the House of Representatives, who is prepared to shirk his responsibility to let his electors know what he is doing and saying should not continue to hold his seat in the Parliament.
- Do the people listen?

- A great many do. Senator Marriott bases his argument on three grounds. The first is that the microphone rules the Parliament. His second is that the broadcasting of parliamentary proceedings is damaging to the prestige of Parliament; and his third ground is that it is distasteful to the listening public. I take his first point, that the microphone rules Parliament. So far as I can glean from Senator Marriott's argument, the only ground he has for making that assertion is that when important speeches are to be made either in another place or in this chamber by prominent members of either the Liberal, Country or Labour party, they are usually delivered at a time when it is believed that most of the general public will be listening. Can it be said that because that is so the microphone rules Parliament? If, for instance, the Prime Minister wished to make a statement of the utmost national importance, is it not natural that he would seek to deliver that statement at a time when most people would be listening? There is nothing wrong with that.

speech.para: It is in the interests of the general public that he should deliver such important statements at times when the majority of the people would be listening. The parties usually agree as to when statements shall be broadcast. For instance, when the Treasurer (Sir Arthur Fadden) is about to introduce his budget, do we not all agree that he should introduce it at a time most suitable to be heard by the great majority of the general public? It is only fair that the listeners should hear the chief speaker for the other side also. I am sure the electors would agree that those speakers should be allowed to broadcast at the time most convenient for the majority of the radio listeners.

Senator Marriott has said that the microphone rules the Parliament, but I do not agree. The honorable senator also said that broadcasting was damaging the prestige of the Parliament. Just what does he mean? That is a matter that rests with individuals. Last night, Senator Brown, who was formerly President of the Senate, gave good reasons why the broadcasting of parliamentary proceedings should be continued. He presided over this chamber for many years, and should know whether the broadcasting of proceedings is an advantage. Senator Mattner, who was also formerly President of the Senate, is in a similar position to judge. Both those honorable senators were here before the proceedings were broadcast, and they are in a better position to judge than is Senator Marriott, who was not here before the broadcasting of proceedings was instituted, although I know that he is sincere and honest in trying to form a judgment.

I believe that we can discard the opinion of Senator Marriott in comparing the quality of the debates before and after the broadcasting of the proceedings was introduced. If the standard of debating has deteriorated, it is no credit to the more recently elected honorable senators. I do not agree with the statement that the standard has fallen. When there was an influx of new senators, which largely changed the appearance of the Senate on the Government side, I remarked at the time that there were some outstanding men among the new senators. The quality of their speeches was very good for a new team, and it has improved since then.

Therefore, on that point I do not agree with Senator Marriott, nor do I agree with Senator Mattner, and if he casts a slur on the debating qualities of his colleagues he does so alone. I did notice that when Senator McMullin was elected to the presidential chair and Senator Mattner vacated it, there was a slight deterioration in the debates on the floor of the chamber. That is the only deterioration that I have noticed.

Senator Marriott has claimed that the broadcasting of proceedings is distasteful to the listening public. I agree that that might be said of some honorable senators and some listeners. Many people do not like to hear the truth, but if it were left to the press they would never get the facts. There was an illustration of that point last night when the honorable member for East Sydney in the House of Representatives (Mr. Ward) delivered one of the most brilliant speeches of his career. Not one line about it appeared in the press to-day, but the Sydney "Daily Telegraph" published a vicious attack on the Senate under the name of Alan Reid, who likes cheap publicity and does not care whether his writing is helpful to Australia or not. The press did not give one line to many speakers in the budget debate in another place, and it did not refer to the opinions expressed in this chamber yesterday by honorable senators, but the scurrilous attack on the Senate was given nearly three columns. Is that the sort of treatment that Senator Marriott expects to get from the press?

Before the proceedings of the Parliament were broadcast, reports in the press were one-sided. The press of Australia is politically biased. How can it give both sides of the picture in such circumstances? Not one newspaper in Australia has given both sides of the proceedings in this Parliament in the past decade. Speeches of honorable members and honorable senators, which should be known to the public, are not given one line in the press. If the people relied on the newspapers they would not know that those members of the Parliament were in Canberra. I know that some members of Parliament are more fortunate and are played up by the press, but those who receive that preference should not kid themselves. It is only temporary. At various times, the press has written up the

Prime Minister (Mr. Menzies), the Acting Prime Minister (Sir Arthur Fadden) and the present Leader of the Opposition (Dr. Evatt) as great men, and within a month or so it has done its best, figuratively speaking, to kick them to death.

talk.start.para: - I thought the honorable senator said that the press was biased.

- I know that Senator Marriott gets a good press in Tasmania. Good luck to him. I give him credit for doing a good job from the Liberal party's point of view, but are his own colleagues getting as good a press in Tasmania? No. It would suit Senator Marriott if the broadcasting of Parliament were discontinued, but it would be detrimental to his colleagues. But would the press suit him next year if he trod on the corns of some of its members? I suggest that that would be a completely different story. The general public should not have to rely solely on the press for information about the doings of Parliament, but is entitled to hear the actual broadcasts of proceedings so that it will be fully informed of the real facts of the matters debated in this place.

speech.para: Senator Mattner said that there is no evidence to show that people have become better informed about the doings of the Parliament since our proceedings have been broadcast. I believe that the speeches that we have heard in this very debate have proved that the people are better informed. Senator Brown said that a person came up to him once and asked him about certain occurrences in the Parliament. Senator Brown was not in the Senate at the time, and he said that he had to talk his way out of that question. I have had much the same experience, and I have discovered that many people listen attentively to the debates in the Parliament and know all about what happens here. They know the nature of the bills before the Parliament and the points in them that may affect them favorably or adversely. I suggest that Senator Mattner has not brought forward any evidence at all to indicate that since the advent of parliamentary broadcasts the people have not become better informed. Indeed, the honorable senator reminds me of the lawyer, cross-examining a witness in court, who asked, " Do you still beat your wife? Answer yes or no ". If the witness answered " yes " he was gone; and if he answered " no " he was also gone. The argument of Senator Mattner followed that line, and would be regarded by some people as a variation of the thimble and pea trick.

The honorable senator also said that the most important part of the debate on any bill took place at the committee stage. Senator Brown said that the debate at the second-reading stage was most important, and should be broadcast. So, of these two ex-Presidents of the Senate, whose views on procedure in the Senate should have some weight, one says that the committee proceedings should be broadcast and the other says that the second-reading proceedings should be broadcast. Therefore, it is quite obvious that the whole of the debate on all bills should be broadcast.

talk.start.para: - The public should hear the speeches during the second-reading debate because in those speeches the general principals of bills are outlined.

- I thank Senator Brown for his assistance, and I agree with him completely. I also agree with Senator Mattner. It is quite obvious that all our proceedings should be broadcast. It is no good trying to kid ourselves that we can hoodwink the people; I am quite sure that we shall never be capable of doing that. If, as has been suggested, it is boring for some people to listen to a long series of divisions being broadcast, it is equally boring for us to have to take part in them.
- Are. we hoodwinking the general public when we pass legislation on Tuesdays and Thursdays - days upon which our proceedings are not broadcast?
- We should be hoodwinking the public if we did not broadcast the whole of our proceedings.
- What about Tuesdays and Thursdays when our proceedings are not broadcast?

- It does not matter what day it is; if the Senate's proceedings are to be broadcast, all of them should be broadcast. I do not agree with the writer of the article, to which I have referred, that the Senate is decaying and is fighting for its survival. On the contrary, the Senate is in a dominant position to-day, whereas the House of Representatives very often has to fight for its survival. The Senate acts as a check on the House of Representatives and, therefore, it is very important that although the public should know what is going on in the other place, it should also know what is going on in the Senate. If honorable members in another place wish to behave at times like a lot of Kilkenny cats, the public should ' know about it, just as they should know when a serious debate is taking place there.

speech.para: I agree with the honorable senators who have stated that the standard of debate in this chamber has improved considerably since our proceedings have been broadcast, and I completely disagree with those senators who have said that it has not so improved. The only way in which it may not have improved is by reason of the fact that Senator Mattner is no longer President, and now takes part in our debates.

talk.start.para: - Senator Aylett cannot help being personal.

- I did not hear what the honorable senator who interjected said, but he is not in a position to judge the standard of debate in this chamber because he has taken his seat here only comparatively recently.
- He would be in a position to judge if he had listened to the broadcasts of our proceedings before he became a senator.

- I thank Senator McCallum for his interjection. Senator Marriott is in no position to tell honorable senators who have been members of the Senate for many years that the standard of debate has deteriorated since the introduction of broadcasting. I for one completely disagree with him.
- I said that the standard of debate deteriorated when our proceedings were being broadcast. Do not misrepresent me.

- Senator Marriott's argument is that the standard of debate has deteriorated because the time allowed honorable senators for speaking has been reduced. I believe that the reduction of the length of speeches has considerably improved our debating standards. If Senator Marriott were to record one of his speeches that lasted for an hour and one of his speeches that lasted for half an how. and then were to listen to them, I am sure that he would agree with me that the shorter speech was better than the longer one. There can be no doubt that shorter speeches are more informative and better in all respects, than long ones. In that respect our position has not deteriorated because when we are not on the air we like to make long speeches such as those referred to by Senator Marriott.
- Stick to the truth.

- I am sticking to the truth right through, because I am speaking as one who has had years of experience in the Senate. Senator Marriott has not had adequate experience to back the opinions that he expressed. Many senators, including myself, can speak of our experience in the Senate both before and after broadcasting was introduced. Many Australians would agree with me that there is no reason why we should wait and see what is done by the House of Commons, the House of Lords, or the House of Representatives or Senate in America. One honorable senator stated that if broadcasting of parliamentary proceedings was a desirable thing, it would have been adopted in the assemblies to which I have just referred. Surely, Australia can go forward on its own initiative without having to follow other countries. Surely, we do not have to follow them like little children.

speech.para: It has been said that the public can be informed about the doings of the Parliament through the pages of " Hansard "; but how many people read " Hansard "? Only a handful of people receive that publication and read it. But apart from broadcasting, " Hansard " is the only means by which the people generally can learn the facts of our debates. It is idle to talk about the press reporting our proceedings, because the press never has given, and never will give, the whole of two sides of any story. Therefore, we are left with " Hansard ", and, as I have said, " Hansard " is read by only a handful of people. If it were not for broadcasting the proceedings of Parliament, only a handful of people in Australia would ever have the opportunity to know what transpired in another place or in this chamber. It is stupid to say that they would get the information from " Hansard ". It is just as -stupid as the comment, " The House of Lords docs not do it. The House of Commons and the Senate of the United States of America do not do it ". Should we stay in the doldrums, hanging behind all the time, or should we take the opportunity to improve the knowledge of the people about Parliament? Why not take the initiative and take advantage of broadcasting? That is what we did when the broadcasting of parliamentary proceedings was introduced. We were not afraid to let the people outside of Parliament know what happened here or to allow them to be the judge, after hearing the speeches of members both here and in another place, whether they would allow us to represent them. If the electors disagree with what their representatives say in speeches broadcast from Parliament they can record their judgment at the ballot-box. Honorable senators and members in another place should never squib the issue, irrespective of what party they belong to, by refusing to express over the air from Parliament their views on a bill or on any other subject.

talk.start.para: . - I am grateful to Senator Marriott for bringing this matter before the Senate, because it requires a good deal of serious attention and debate. Perhaps there are some evils which have attended the broadcasting of parliamentary proceedings, but I am not prepared to admit that Senator Marriott, or any other honorable senator who has supported this motion, has proved his case. One of the arguments is that the standard of debate has declined considerably since parliamentary proceedings have been broadcast, but I am not convinced of that. A little while ago I read the report of a debate which took place in this House 35 years ago, and of a similar debate in another place, and - it pains me to record

speech.para: I did not think, their views' profound or their conclusions well assured.
I thought it was one of the feeblest debates I had ever read.

Long before broadcasting of parliamentary proceedings was introduced, I sat in the galleries of various legislatures - in both Houses of the New South Wales Parliament, in the South Australian House of Assembly, in both Houses of the Federal Parliament when it met in Melbourne, and in the House of Commons. Although I listened to good debates in all those places, many speeches were of a low standard. lt has been argued that when Parliament is being broadcast members and senators forget about the relevance of their remarks 10 the subject or the bill under discussion, and address themselves to the multitude outside. That sort of thing happened long before broadcasting of parliamentary proceedings was introduced. In 1821, during the sixteenth Congress of the United States of America, a gentleman named Felix Walker, who represented a district of North Carolina, was speaking at inordinate length and apparently to the complete boredom of his audience. Congressmen started to shout, " Question! Question! ", but according to the record, he persisted, saying that he was " bound to make a speech for Buncombe ". Buncombe happened to be a county in his district. That incident has given a new word to the language, because " buncombe " now means " irrelevant and specious matter " and has finally come to mean " nonsense ". That happened before the broadcasting of parliament, and I doubt whether there is more of it now than in those days.

Two tests can be applied to determine whether Senator Marriott's contentions are correct. One is by comparing the debates recorded in " Hansard " before parliamentary broadcasting was introduced with those recorded since its introduction, and I doubt whether any deterioration in the standard of debate will be found. Good speakers and poor speakers contributed to the debates in both periods. Another, and easier, test is to compare debates when parliament was on the air with those when it was not. Good debates have taken place when Parliament was not being broadcast, and also extremely good debates have taken place when it was on the air. The speeches of individual senators do not vary greatly. As far as I am concerned, the speech I am now making is exactly the same as it would have been if Parliament were not on the air. I would have prepared it in the same way and would have expressed the same thoughts in the same sort of language as I am now addressing to you, Mr. President. In another place, an honorable member once seemed to forget that he was addressing the House and devoted his attention to the uncounted multitude outside, but he was soon stopped by the Speaker and reminded that he was addressing the Chair. Most honorable senators in this House always realize that they are speaking to the Chair and to their fellow senators. In my opinion, there is no conclusive evidence that the standard of debate has deteriorated since the broadcasting of parliamentary proceedings was introduced. The evidence is either neutral or the other way.

A curious argument was used by Senator Marriott, that over the air the voice of a speaker was very important. That may be so, but is not the voice equally important in the House or at a public meeting? A microphone improves the sound of some voices. If a speaker has a weak voice or if his voice is monotonous, its volume will be increased and its quality will sound far better over the air, and although people in his immediate audience may not care for it, the radio listeners may gain a very favorable impression. That argument of Senator Marriott's may therefore be dismissed. The Leader of the Opposition (Senator McKenna) said that whatever value may come to a man because of his voice and presentation, what counts most in any speech is the matter and the force with which it is delivered. I have heard speakers whose voices at close range were not attractive but who, over the air, conveyed the impression that they were possessed of sound knowledge and were able to present their matter in a vigorous and convincing fashion.

talk.start.para: - That may be only from the point of view of the Senate. The public might get a wrong impression.

- That may be so, but whether there is a microphone or not, the quality of the matter and the way in which it is presented counts most. It is true that the various undertones and overtones of the human voice may be given a different quality over the air.

speech.para: It is necessary that the electors should know what Parliament is doing, and the more they know about it the better, and the closer the guard they can keep on our proceedings the safer will be our democracy. lt is a fact that the press reports far less of what happens in Parliament than it used to. I do not intend to join in an attack on the press, nor do I agree with certain sentiments which I heard expressed a little earlier, that the press is never fair, but the amount of political matter reported in the press is far smaller than it used to be. No debates are now reported as fully as in former years. There was a time when even trivial debates in Parliament were fully reported. 1 can remember, as a boy, reading the parliamentary debates in the newspapers, and all the characters in that period, not only in the Parliament of New South Wales, but also in most parliaments throughout Australia were well known to me. At this instant, I recall reading a report in the Sydney press of a speech delivered in the Queensland Parliament by Mr. Kidston, who was then the Premier of that State. To-day, we read very little in the Sydney press about proceedings in other States, and not enough about what happens in the Commonwealth Parliament, or even in the Parliament of New South Wales. Now, radio broadcasts remedy that lack for those who wish to listen. Those who do not wish to listen need not do so. People who talk about the dullness of parliamentary broadcasts should always remember that any listener can turn the knob of the radio. That is one of the great attractions of broadcasting - a listener can extinguish a speaker whom he does not like. If he finds the speaker irritating, all he has to do is to turn the dial of his radio receiver and be regaled with some pleasant music or some other programme. Sometimes amusing results follow from turning to another station. I recall an incident when I heard an emphatic assertion made by someone in Parliament, and when I tuned to another station the announcer at that moment said, " This station will tell you another fairy story next week ".

One of the men who developed radio in New South Wales, the late Theo Matthews, said to me, when broadcasting was first introduced, " I find it boring, but it is very valuable that Parliament should be on tap ". Any citizen can find out what kind of representative he has. Let there be no mistake, it is not always the showman, who has been attacked in this debate, the man who sets out to convince the people that he is the important fellow, who wins the people's favour. Very often, a quiet remark is a thing that sticks in the listeners memory. I can say that from my own experience. When broadcasting was introduced I took to listening to Parliament whenever I could. 1 soon got to know all the speakers, everybody who spoke often and every prominent man in both

Houses, and I knew what to expect. If a man got boring, I simply noted the time and made a rough calculation as to when he would finish, switched off the radio and switched it on again when he was finished. I sometimes listened to boring and disagreeable matter, as a mortification to the flesh maybe, but also because I wanted to know what people were doing.

That brings me to the very important point that has been raised as to whether we could edit parliamentary broadcasts, as to whether we could give some, but not all, of the proceedings. I can find no just way of doing this. I know it would be much more agreeable to broadcast only the high-lights of debates and cut out the tedious speakers. But we must not forget that often it is the tedious speaker who brings out some important truth that a more brilliant speaker may be seeking to hide. And do not forget, either, that one often gets a great surge of thought coming suddenly from a man from whom one did not expect to get it. I can say that there were very few of the people I listened to when I was not in Parliament who did not at some time say something that was worth saying. As for those who did not, well, at least I was able to form my opinion of them. I was able to say, " These are not the sort of people we want in Parliament ".

Another argument that has been used is that when we are not on the air we can speak at considerably greater length, whereas when we are on the air we are tied by a gentleman's agreement to condense our speeches. I cannot find anything more salutary. The most valuable exercise I ever had in my life in expressing myself was when I had to write fourminute commentaries for the Australian Broadcasting Commission. Into four minutes I had to compress something of substance, something that was not just a mere idle remark. Those four-minute commentaries often took much more time to prepare than a long lecture would. It is one of the most valuable of all exercises to compel one to make his thoughts succinct and to get rid of all irrelevant, extraneous and illustrative matter.

talk.start.para: - Why not make those conditions apply always?

- That is a different question. If we could alter the rules of this chamber we could make half an hour the maximum length of an ordinary speech; but I shall not go into that. I merely say that the necessity to condense one's remarks within half an hour is not an evil, and, therefore, broadcasting cannot be condemned on that account.

speech.para: Senator Mattner put forward one or two arguments with which I find I cannot agree. For instance, he said that all those who had spoken before him had admitted that broadcasting was unreal. I do not admit that. I think that speeches such as we have heard to-day are much the same as they would be if they were not being broadcast. I think that this question has been debated as a question, without any particular attempt to impress people who may be listening in. I am sure that citizens who are listening to us get a far better impression if they know we are debating a matter and addressing the Chair and our fellow senators and not the public.

As to divisions, that is perhaps a rather difficult matter; but it is not very often in parliamentary life, certainly not in this chamber, that there is division after division. Those are things that arise only when some considerable degree of party feeling arises, when one party believes that the other party has done something against which it must protest. I know that the Leader of the Opposition (Senator McKenna) has quite frequently taken a test division and has said, "We will let that stand; that will be the test without other divisions to follow. We know we can take a division on everything but as all the senators are here we will let the matter stand at that." I think that might well become more general.

talk.start.para: - More divisions take place in another place.

- I know there are more divisions in another place. If the citizen is to know how Parliament acts, even listening to divisions is part of his education. After all, it is well he should know that Parliament is not all beer and skittles, that a good deal of it is drudgery and that members are here to do their duty according to how they see it; and that is what a person does when he sits in a division.

speech.para: I deplore the fact that some of the better programmes are put off by the Australian Broadcasting. Commission when parliamentary broadcasts come on. That is something we should try to remedy if we can. As the country becomes more populous and as we have more stations and more programmes, that could be remedied; but it is idle to say that because some people want to listen to an opera, or an oratorio, therefore one should not have the opportunity to listen to a debate in Parliament. The two things cannot be compared. It is no good saying that one is better than the other because they are in totally different categories. Music is one of the most sublime things in the world, and it is good that our citizens should have the. opportunity to listen to the greatest of the arts. However, the legislators are also important and it is of the utmost importance that the citizens should know what sort of people they are. What would it profit the music lover if democracy were swept away and if our free Government went and we got some dictator who said, " You must not listen to that particular opera; you must not listen to that kind of music ". I am reminded of the lunatic who was walking down the streets of Sydney and suddenly asked, " Is this Pitt-street or Thursday? " He was comparing two totally different things that were not comparable. A debate, whether it be great or ordinary, cannot be compared with great music, literature or art. Sometimes, however, debates have given rise to great literature. I do not know whether anything of thai kind has arisen as a result of the broadcasting of parliamentary proceedings, but certainly some of the mighty debates in the past have given rise to great literature.

I ask honorable senators to reject this motion. I have listened with the pro.foundest respect to the arguments put forward in favour of it. 1 know that the motive behind it is a good one, but I do not think a case has been made out. It is not true that broadcasting has brought all these evils upon us and I conclude by saying that broadcasting has brought us some positive benefits. Among those positive benefits is the fact that any citizen can listen to parliamentary debates, whether he owns a wireless or merely has to borrow it, and he can get to know the character and ability of the members. Furthermore, he can follow in a fairly full way the matters which come before Parliament, and the types of arguments that are used. Finally, Parliament is brought, in a way, into closer touch with the people than ever before. 1 have followed the politics of this country and of other countries ever since my childhood and have always felt that I knew something about leading public figures. When I came to this chamber, although there were few of the senators 1 had met before, none of them were strangers to me. I had formed an opinion of their character and ability, which time has modified slightly, but has not greatly changed. Therefore, I say that this instrument of broadcasting can be made one of the greatest safeguards of democracy, and I ask this chamber not to sanction its abolition.

talk.start.para: . - I consider that the introduction of this subject has given us an opportunity to review an innovation in the Australian Parliament that has now had a reasonable period of trial and ought to be subjected to our scrutiny. I have had the honour to be a Senate representative on the committee controlling the broadcasting of parliamentary proceedings since the inception of the experiment. I believe that the broadcasting of parliamentary proceedings is probably the greatest aid to the democratic system that has been introduced in any of the parliaments of the world. I do not agree with the contention that, because some older countries have not seen the wisdom of enabling the people to learn what happens in their parliament through the medium of radio, we should abandon the experiment. Rather do I feel that we have given a lead to other countries, and I look forward confidently to those other countries gradually falling into line by broadcasting the proceedings in the respective parliaments to their people.

speech.para: I have been very interested to learn of the reactions of honorable senators to parliamentary broadcasts. I should have liked to hear more about the general principle of the broadcasting of parliamentary desome of the minor defects that are obvious in the broadcast of the proceedings. It is perfectly true that, since the introduction of having our debates broadcast than about bates, we have become more conscious of the microphone and that, to a degree, broadcasting has modified the proceedings of the Parliament. To a degree, also, it has dictated the way in which certain debates are conducted, and has exercised a very great influence on our proceedings. To use current colloquialism, " So what? " What does it matter? Were we presenting the Parliament to the people in the best way before broadcasting was introduced? Were there no defects in those days in the manner in which we conducted our proceedings? Have not the consequential changes been of benefit both to the Parliament and to the people of Australia? It is true that the introduction of the microphone has brought about certain changes in our proceedings, but I believe that they have been for the betterment both of the Parliament and of the people who listen to parliamentary broadcasts. I am not impressed in any way by the argument that we have become slaves to the microphone. I do not believe that to be true; but I do agree that broadcasting has modified our proceedings, without introducing any serious impediment to the carrying on of the business of this Parliament.

Senator Mattner said that the form of questions has changed since the introduction of the broadcast of parliamentary proceedings. I contest that assertion. My mind goes back to the days before broadcasting. The questions that were asked in those days were very similar to- those that are asked now when we are on the air. They contained a good deal of party political matter and were not asked in order to assist the Government. In many instances, their purpose was to score a point, if possible, as well as to obtain information. I do not think that the form of questions has altered very much since those days except, perhaps, that to-day questions are a little clearer than formerly because members of the Parliament devote a little more time to the framing of them. In my opinion, question time has become more interesting than it was before the advent of parliamentary broadcasting.

It has been said that the Parliament is not well presented on the air, that there is too much noise and that, therefore, listeners might gain the impression that we tend to get quarrelsome and want to fight, and so on. After all, this is not a model debating society, or a place of entertainment. It is the Parliament of the Commonwealth of Australia, and is composed of all types of men, from all walks of life, some of whom have had a very harsh upbringing, while others have been more fortunate. In presenting their views to the Parliament, by the very nature of things some members are more vigorous than others. The Parliament is a cross section of the Australian people. Gathered here are the representatives of all sections of the nation who, both in this chamber and in another place, express their opinions on how Australia ought to be managed. At times, they do so with a great deal of feeling. Always, they put to the Parliament the views of the sections of the community that they represent. They do not always express themselves academically, but usually do so vigorously. If the Australian people have conveyed to them the impression that occasionally this Parliament is a place of turmoil and great emotion, that is a very real impression. In any parliament, it must be expected that there will be clashes of opinion, due to the different environments in which the representatives of the people have received their training over the years.

I come now to the reason why, some ten years ago, it was decided to broadcast the parliamentary proceedings. Older members of the Parliament will recall that, prior to the advent of parliamentary broadcasts, we were as poorly presented to the people by the press of this country as we are to-day. Not only were reports of our proceedings had, but they were very often quite inaccurate, and the members of the Parliament had no redress. I recall getting very hot on one or two occasions when the press attributed to me statements quite the reverse of what I had said. I wrote to the various editors on the matter, but 1 do not know whether or not they considered it worth their while reading my letters, because I received no replies. In those circumstances, an elector might say to me, " You said so and so in the Parliament " when, in fact, I had said directly the opposite. In those days there was no way in which the members of the Parliament could have their statements here accurately presented to the Australian people.

Secondly, before the introduction of the system of parliamentary broadcasts, there was a tendency for some members of the Parliament to stunt and to ask odd questions for the sole purpose of gaining added publicity through the press. Very often men who had prepared thoughtful speeches and who had contributed something of value to the Parliament found that the press made no reference whatever to what they had said. I know that many men became disheartened when they found, after having worked on speeches in order to deliver something worthwhile in Parliament, that the only record of those speeches was in " Hansard " and that the general public knew nothing about what they had said whilst, on the other hand, a member might rise in the chamber, use strong language, or take advantage of some political stunt and in that way receive headlines in the Australian press the following day. We felt that this was not conducive to getting the best that it was possible to get from the Parliament. We knew we were completely at the mercy of the Press. I can remember when this chamber was held to ridicule several times by the press. If I remember rightly, when Senator Brown was President he found it necessary to exclude the press from the Senate for a period because of the inaccurate and frivolous reports that were being published about the Senate while honorable senators had no way of obtaining any redress.

After the Parliamentary Proceedings Broadcasting Committee furnished its report, the Government decided to conduct an experiment by putting Parliament over the air for some part of the day. We entered into discussions with the Australian Broadcasting Commission and were told by that body that it was prepared to allow a Government speaker to have ten minutes a night, and an Opposition speaker to have ten minutes a night, while one of its own commentators would have a further ten minutes to sum up the proceedings of Parliament. We felt that this was not good enough so we went further than we intended to go originally and passed legislation compelling the Australian Broadcasting Commission to broadcast the proceedings of this Parliament. We began by broadcasting the whole of the proceedings of the Parliament. Since then, we have made many changes iri the system. For instance, as has been mentioned already, we ceased broadcasting the proceedings during the debate on the adjournment. That was done because, occasionally, it was found that members made violent attacks on people outside the Parliament, and although those attacks were broadcast through the Commonwealth the person who was attacked had no redress other than to ask the Australian press to take up his case on his behalf. Because of those happenings we decided that discussion during the adjournment should not be broadcast. -

Again, we have made some changes in relation to the broadcasting of questions. We found that some Ministers had a tendency to read long statements at question-time in order to get certain matters over the air twice in the one day. We had to prohibit that practice. Over the years we have tried to present the proceedings of the Parliament to the people in the most attractive way whilst, at the same time, ensuring that both sides shall have a fair share of the broadcasting time. That is of vast importance in our democratic system of government. We have two major parties in the Parliament. We believed that they were not being given equal opportunities by the press of Australia to express their views. We believed that it is good for any democratic system that both sides of the Parliament should have equal opportunities to express their views. We believed that the Government should have full opportunity to state its reason for proposing laws and that the Opposition should have equal opportunity to state its reasons for opposing proposed measures. Under the present system, any person who cares to devote a day or two to preparing a speech will know that when he delivers it he will have an audience of Australian people who are likely to listen to what he puts forward. We know that under our present system both the Government and the Opposition sides have equal opportunities to express their views to the Australian people. It is important to know also that the general public, merely by turning a switch is able to listen to what is happening in the Australian Parliament. That must be of great aid to our democratic way of life. It must be very encouraging to all those people who believe in democracy to know that by turning a switch they are given the opportunity to listen to arguments both for and against matters under discussion in the National Parliament. They know that their democratic way of life is being protected, and I feel that by introducing the broadcasting of parliamentary proceedings we have established one of the greatest means of preserving democracy in recent years.

Mention has been made of the televising of the proceedings of the Parliament. Television is another innovation, lt was many years before we were prepared to introduce the broadcasting of proceedings as we know it to-day. I think that many parliamentarians thought that the broadcasting of their speeches was too intimate, that it, perhaps, would reveal too clearly the lack of capacity of some members to speak. Perhaps, many parliamentarians feel to-day that television at this stage might not be of any advantage; but it is one of the new media of communication and I believe it will have to be considered in the years to come. I believe that just as we met the challenge of radio so will we meet the challenge of television.

Here, it is interesting to recall that when we began to broadcast the proceedings of Parliament, Senator Brown, who was then President of the Senate, sought to allay the fears of a number of senators. He obtained a tape recorder and recorded speeches made by those senators who were fearful about how their utterances would be received over the air. The tape recording was played back to the senators concerned, and in this way the then President was able to give tremendous help to honorable senators by giving them some idea of what their speeches would sound like over the air. Just as Senator Brown made a challenge on that occasion, so also I am sure that if we were determined to enter television, Mr. President, you would ensure that honorable senators were properly schooled before they appeared on that medium.

I am grateful to Senator Marriott for introducing a debate on this matter. The effectiveness of radio broadcasting of the proceedings of the Parliament has been discussed. Some assessments have been made of the numbers of listeners. Public opinion polls have shown that more than 50 per cent, want the broadcasting of parliamentary proceedings to be continued, but other surveys have suggested that only two or three per cent, of the people listen to those broadcasts. I suspect those figures, and I believe that they might have been obtained in the big cities. As I have moved around the country, I have found that the people are so well informed on the proceedings of Parliament that there must be a large radio audience listening fairly closely to the parliamentary debates. That is true, iri particular, of the country areas where it is difficult to get up-to-date news, and the broadcasts from the Parliament must be very welcome to those people.

I believe that this form of communication has proved a huge success after ten years of experimentation. It has now become part of the Australian way of life, and it is inseparable from the proceedings of the Parliament. The people of Australia are better informed than they were in the past. I believe that if we want to preserve democracy and our way of life we should retain the interest of the people in our democratic form of government. To do that, we must use the most effective medium of communication so that we shall keep our parliamentary debates before the people. Therefore, I ask honorable senators to reject the motion that has been moved by Senator Marriott.

talk.start.para: .- First, I should like to congratulate Senator Marriott on bringing forward this motion. I. do not say that because I believe there is any merit in his proposal, or because of the content of the motion as such, but because Senator Marriott has taken advantage of the forms of the Senate to submit something in which he believes personally. He has endeavoured to get the Parliament to alter an existing state of affairs through the proper forms of Parliament that are open to a private member. I believe that more use should be made of the forms of this House. Far more time should be given to presenting and considering private members' bills and motions. That is the first ground upon which I should like to congratulate Senator Marriott.

speech.para: I congratulate him also because he has managed to present the Senate with a matter that has had a result which is almost unique in my experience of the Senate proceedings. This proposal has evoked more unanimity than any that I have heard discussed previously in this chamber, including proposals which one would have expected to be received without a dissentient voice.

So far as I know, every honorable senator, with the exception of Senator Marriott, is against the proposal he has presented. At any rate, there is a great body of opinion against it, and I congratulate Senator Marriott on having submitted the basis for such sweet reasonableness and agreeableness between both sides of the chamber.

I believe, however, that it would be a tragedy if we agreed to the proposal he has put forward. Every parliament should have the widest potential publicity that is available to it in the country where it operates. One of the first steps that is taken by any person who wishes to suppress parliamentary government, or to mislead the people about the doings and sayings of their representatives, is to prevent full and free publicity. While there is, in both Houses of the Parliament, a medium which gives to all the people who are interested full access to parliamentary proceedings, it will be extremely difficult for any attempt to overthrow parliamentary government to succeed. I am not sure that in the years to come such an attempt will not be made in Australia.
