The radio broadcasting of the proceedings of the Parliament is an insurance - an insurance policy, if I might describe it as such - guaranteeing the survival of parliamentary government in Australia. In this case, as with all insurance policies, a premium has to be paid. I admit that the premium payments include the necessity to listen, on many occasions, to dull and repetitious speeches, such as the one I am now delivering, instead of listening to a commercial broadcasting station, but that is a premium that the public should pay. If they pay for it, they will be repaid over and over again by the preservation of the firmest and widest foundation of their freedom.

We have seen in Australia attempts, and beginnings of attempts, to place media of propaganda and the dissemination of information into fewer and fewer hands. At one stage in this chamber, note was taken of an attempt to amalgamate a large network of radio stations under the control of overseas capital. We have seen successful attempts to amalgamate newspapers. There is strong reason to believe that the overseas capital to which I have referred is endeavouring to start a chain of newspapers in Australia. li already controls one large Melbourne daily newspaper, the "Argus", and it is believed in financial circles that the same interests are endeavouring to buy another large Melbourne daily newspaper, the " Age ". If those interests are successful in that attempt, and if this tendency continues, the press of Australia and the broadcasting stations are likely to fall into fewer and fewer hands under the control of capital that comes from outside Australia and from unknown sources.

talk.start.para: - We get the truth if there is a bit of competition.

- I am sorry that I have been so obscure in my speech, or the interjector so dense, that it has not been made apparent that competition is daily becoming less and less, that there is more and more lack of competition and that the broadcasting of parliamentary proceedings becomes more and more necessary and not less and less necessary if the public are to be assured of a full appreciation of what is going on. I know that a number of unimportant and tedious matters have to be listened to, but it is quite impossible for any senator or member of the Parliament of any party, to decide what is important and what is not important in the broadcasts of parliamentary proceedings. If the Prime Minister is to address the House of Representatives on a matter of foreign affairs, the participation of this country in defence agreements, or on economic and budget matters - all things in which a vast number of people are interested - almost every one will agree that he will have an immense listening audience throughout the country. Thousands and thousands of people listen to the Prime Minister (Mr. Menzies) and thousands and thousands wish to listen to the Leader of the Opposition (Dr. Evatt) when replying on the same matter.

speech.para: Once we endeavour to limit the broadcasting of our proceedings to matters which the man in the street might regard as important, we give to the government in power at the moment, whether it be on our side or on the other side, a power to discriminate between what it considers important and what it considers is not important - a power to say, "That is not important" whereas it might be extremely important to the Opposition and the public. Such a thing would not be right. Any power residing in any commission or body to decide what is important and what is not important in parliamentary proceedings would be far too great, and should not be given in any circumstances.

The proposer of the motion at present before the Senate asked a number of questions during his speech which he thought would elicit answers favorable to his case. He asked first, " Does the microphone rule Parliament? " and put forward his contention that it does, based on the arguments that we all heard. However, his arguments did not for one moment prove that the microphone rules the Parliament. It is true that the members of the Parliament and those responsible for the business of the Parliament take note of the existence of the microphone when making speeches or preparing the order of business. They wish to have an important speech put over the air at 8 o'clock, perhaps, when the vast majority of people who listen to the Parliament will be listening. But that is not a proof that the microphone is the ruler of Parliament. One might as well say that, because a farmer uses a tractor to plough his land and does not follow the same routine as when he used a horse, the plough rules the farmer rather than the farmer rules the plough. I do not believe for one moment that the argument that the microphone rules Parliament can be sustained.

talk.start.para: asked, " Does the broadcasting of Parliament lower its prestige? It is difficult to answer that question because I have not been able to discover what is the prestige of Parliament. Abour four out of seven of the people one meets seem to have very little regard for the prestige of Parliament, certainly very little for the members of Parliament and certainly none at all for the particular representative to whom they happen to be speaking. On the other hand, there seem to be numbers of other people who feel that the Parliament does do something sometimes to help them or prevent them from being victimized, and that the members of it - particularly at some special time when they are asking for some special thing - should be treated with a certain amount of deference. So, it is hard to find out what the prestige of Parliament is, and, therefore, to find out whether the use of the facilities of broadcasting does or does not lower that prestige.

speech.para: However, if it has been lowered by broadcasting, it is pretty obvious that it started to be lowered ten years ago and will not be lowered more by continuing a practice which has gone on for ten years. I, personally, do not think that broadcasting lowers the Parliament's prestige. In the old days when one read a newspaper report and saw " jeers and catcalls " in brackets after parts of a speech, or " blows exchanged over the Speaker's table ", that was just as liable to be detrimental to the prestige of the Parliament as is the rather dignified way in which we manage to conduct ourselves in this Senate - which is the only chamber that I should refer to in these particular terms. Therefore, I do not agree that the use of the microphone does lower the prestige of the Parliament.

Senator Marriott's last question was, " Do the people want it, or don't they? " That question has been answered over and over again in this chamber, and I shall recapitulate that the gallup poll indicates that the majority of the people do want it. The gallup poll is very nearly infallible. Before the last general election it indicated that the people wanted the present Government to be returned, and look what happened! The gallup poll indicates that the people strongly favour this Government at the present time, and that is true. Therefore, the gallup poll indicating that the majority of people want the broadcasting of parliamentary proceedings to continue must be taken. to be a true and favorable expression of the majority will of the people; and I am certain that my friends opposite will agree with me on that.

We were told by Senator Anderson that one in six of the people listen to the broadcasting of parliamentary proceedings' at some time or other. I do not know how surveys to find out information such as that are conducted, or if they count among the listeners to Parliament those people who switch the radio on, inadvertently turn to the parliamentary broadcast and then hurriedly switch it off again. If that is not part of the basis of these calculations, and if the survey applies to people who listen to our broadcasts for a quarter of an hour, or half an hour or so, then one in six is an immensely large listening audience, which any commercial firm would pay millions and millions of pounds to get for a show advertising its products. If Mr. Dyer, or Mr. Davey, were able to point to an audience of one in six of all radio listeners throughout Australia, they would be paid far more fabulous salaries than they are understood to get at the present time. Therefore, all the indications are that the majority of people want the broadcasting of our proceedings to continue, and that a large number of them listen to those broadcasts. Having said that, I agree with the mover of this motion that a vocal minority of the people definitely do not want it. However, for the reasons that I gave at the beginning of my speech, I do not believe that that vocal minority should be allowed to prevail. I do not think that they would be happy in the outcome if they were allowed to prevail, and, consequently, 1 join the vast majority of honorable senators who trust that this motion will be ignominiously defeated.

talk.start.para: .- As the Minister of the Crown who was privileged to introduce the bill to establish the broadcasting of parliamentary proceedings, I was then, and am now, an enthusiastic supporter of the process. Broadcasting is an appeal to the collective mind as distinct from the individual mind. The written word is an appeal mainly to the individual mind, but broadcasting is an appeal - and a greater appeal than has ever eventuated before - to the collective mind. In my opinion, it has been much more effective and objective than any other appeal which has been made, and I judge it mainly by the adverse criticism to which I myself am sometimes subjected, and the adverse criticism to which honorable members on the Government side are subjected. That indicates that as a result of what the people have heard over the radio they are thinking for themselves independently of those who represent them. I am reminded of the ancient Greek philosopher, Epictetus, who welcomed adverse criticism to a far greater extent than he appreciated favorable comment. In effect, he said that most applause is selfapplause. That is as true now as it was then. All that we succeed in saying is what the listeners conclude from our words. Our statements may not have added anything at all to their knowledge, but when a speaker is subjected to hard-hitting, adverse criticism and is put on his defence, it is proof positive that he has said something to make people think. That has been my experience. I have grown up with the Labour movement in this country since 1890, or thereabouts, and I have had considerable experience in organizing workers and in advocating what were considered to be impossible propositions. The adverse criticism to which I was subjected - as were others also - proved to me then, as it proves to me to-day, that if one said something provocative and constructive, it made people think. That was my main purpose in visiting country districts and towns. I met all sorts of people in various occupations and branches of social activities and they often asked me my opinion on a certain matter. They would say, "What are you doing about this? " I would ask, " What do you mean? " and they would reply, " We heard about this over the air ".

speech.para: To-day, I received a telephone call from a critic in Sydney who is well known in the Labour movement. He said that he had listened last night to the speeches of the Leader of the Opposition in another place (Dr. Evatt) and of the honorable member for East Sydney (Mr. Ward) and others, but when he read the press report this morning he found it was nothing like what he had heard. That report was simply a condensation of what was said, written to suit the editors of the newspaper and in order to influence the public mind. That is exactly what happens since the press has become controlled by a monopoly to a far greater extent than ever before. For all practical purposes, the press is expressing a monopoly point of view. That opinion was expressed to me only this morning. Another proof of the degeneracy of the press is the comic strips which it publishes, to appeal to' the primitive minds and the infantile imagination of its readers. There is nothing forthright or constructive in the public press to-day as compared with what was published in the 1890's and the years immediately following. Consequently, broadcasting is a corrective which should be supported by everybody. It teaches people to think for themselves. The press plays down what is said, and although, as Senator McCallum suggested, a speech may be, good or bad, the final question the speaker has to ask himself is: Who is to judge? The judgment depends upon the point of view of the listeners.

My experience, gained from addressing public meetings and speaking to workers on the job, is that the listeners are forming impressions. They are thinking for themselves and they want to know, as they have asked me thousands of times, " Why is this done, in the light of what is happening? " Even to-day they want to know why the Prime Minister (Mr. Menzies) is in Egypt, in view of what he has said previously. This is all valuable because the people are [earning to think for themselves. We may not agree with their conclusions, but what people have to learn to-day more than anything else is to think for themselves and not be merely mental dependants or followers of those who speak in the name of authority. There are those who believe that when a British authority makes a statement he speaks ex cathedra and that the truth of his utterances is beyond question. That is entirely wrong.

Before the broadcasting of parliamentary proceedings was instituted, and when the proposal to do so was being debated, 1 advocated its adoption, particularly after I heard the views of representatives of New Zealand who were then in Canberra. My friend, Senator Mattner, said, among other things, that broadcasting of parliamentary proceedings had not by any means raised the level of debates. What I am about to say is only elementary psychology, but I suggest that by a process of mental projection the honorable senator is attributing to others the very trait which he himself possesses but deplores. His statement reveals what he thinks of the people with whom he is associated and he is adopting a doctrinaire attitude which is not justified. If what the honorable senator says is true, it is the fault of the members of this House and not of the people outside. If one is not interested in adding to his knowledge any more than is necessary to retain his seat as a member of parliament or as a judge of the High Court or some other official position, he must be prepared to be regarded with a considerable amount of suspicion. Sir Ian Clunies Ross, chairman of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organization, when speaking at the University of Melbourne on 13th August last, stated that scientists are ill equipped - those were his own words - to understand political problems. I agree with him. That applies generally. They have specialized in particular problems, but outside those problems they are simply babes in the wood in their political thinking. That was the implication of his statement and others have said it before. It was said in 1 844 by Karl Marx. It was said in 1931, by William McDougall, the leading physiological psychologist in England, and, last but not least by a leading biologist, Dr. Alexis Carrel, in 1935 in the publication known as " Man the Unknown ". On page 40 of the second chapter he said -

quote.para: The science of man is the most important of all sciences and least understood.

speech.para: One may excell in the physical sciences, such as law. Law is based on precedent and that is why most of the lawyers go back to the medieval ages. Of course, there are the exceptions. What applies to lawyers applies to scientists, engineers, and others who excel in a technical capacity in one field, but outside that field have little knowledge. Dr. Alexis Carrel had in mind the non-specialist sciences. In other words, he had in mind the synthetic scientists, men who have a knowledge of a special branch of science and still have a working knowledge of other sciences. In my opinion social science is the science least understood in this and similar institutions.

There would never be any war if people were reasonably well-educated and that applies not only in this country but generally. I should like to preface what I have to say about my own experience by referring to the advocate or protagonist of a new idea. By an idea I mean a plan for action. That is my interpretation of the word " idea ". The new idea passes through three stages, and this has been the case ever since man has been able to speak. First of all, there is uncompromising hostility because the idea is in conflict with old ideas. Then, in the light of sustained discussion, agitation and debate there is critical toleration and, subsequently, in the light of the success of the idea, there is unanimous approval. Those are the mental processes through which we go and it is due mainly to our system of education.

Therefore, I welcome with open arms the broadcasting of parliamentary proceedings so that one can express his ideas as he feels and people can judge for themselves without relying on the press or even on " Hansard " because, as one honorable senator said, very few people read " Hansard ". That has been my experience, too. The fact is that very few people have time to read " Hansard ". Take the waterside worker, the miner or even the entrepreneur in charge of a big business - they have to concentrate on the one thing all the time, and while a person is concentrating on one proposition he loses sight of the fact that we are living in a changing world and, therefore, cannot understand what should be done. I ask for leave to continue my remarks at a later date.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.
Sitting suspended from 5.45 to 8 p.m.

debate.para: Debate resumed from 30th August (vide page 39), on motion by Senator Spooner -

quote.para: That the following papers be printed: -
Estimates of Receipts and Expenditure, and Estimates of Expenditure for Additions, New Works, and other Services involving Capital Expenditure, for the year ending 30th June, 1957,
The Budget 1956-57 - Papers presented by the Right Hon. Sir Arthur Fadden in connexion with the Budget of 1956-57, and
National Income and Expenditure 1955-56.

talk.start.para: . - The Senate now has before it the Estimates and Budget papers and is considering a formal motion that these papers be printed. As every member of this chamber knows, this is a device merely to enable early debate on the budget proposals to take place in this chamber. We cannot, of course, deal with the budget itself until it comes to us in the form of appropriation bills' from the House of Representatives. We received the papers now before us on Thursday last, and I can indicate to the Senate that to peruse their 500 pages in the few days that have intervened since then has been a considerable task. When I point out that budgets are mostly composed of figures and statistics, one can realize the magnitude of the task of trying to survey, in the course of a few days, the whole ambit of Commonwealth activity.

speech.para: I say at once that there is not one word in the dictionary that I know of that is strong enough to condemn this budget, lt has been described variously as sterile, heartless, barren and hopeless. It follows the same old futile policies that the Government has announced in the last six or seven years and, of course, it is open to exactly the same criticisms that the Opposition has levelled against those policies consistently and honestly over the whole period. One newspaper I noted, very brightly, if somewhat inadequately, described this budget as the budget that does not budge. That is not a bad description of it, because it is the most static thing that the Opposition has ever cast eyes upon. We of the Opposition regard this budget so seriously that we propose to treat it with more than usual formality. Therefore, on behalf of the Opposition, I move -

quote.para: That all words after "That" be left out, with a view to insert in lieu thereof, " the estimates and Budget Papers 1956-57 tabled in the Senate are unacceptable and should be rejected because they seek to implement policies which arc seriously detrimental in their effect on the interests of Australia, and for which the Government deserves to be censured '".

speech.para: You, Mr. President, might recognize this as a somewhat unusual course to follow on a motion of this type, but the Opposition feels that it is time to direct very pointed attention to the policies that are being pursued. Right at the outset, I want to comment upon a usual feature of the introduction of budgets by this Government. There has been on this occasion, as on others, a disgraceful leakage of the contents of the budget in the press. Information on some items was known weeks before, and on others some days before even the confidential pre-release of the budget to the newspapers to enable them to set it up. So, the blame for these leakages on this occasion cannot be laid at the door of the press of the country, and the Government and its supporters must accept responsibility for what has happened. Long before the budget was tabled, we read in the press that there would be no reductions in the rates -of taxation, no increases in pension rates, and that there would be increased postal -charges. Those things were asserted, not by way of speculation, but dogmatically, and the Government must accept full responsibility for the disclosures however they occurred. There was an extraordinary advertisement in the Sydney press in the very first edition on the morning following the introduction of the budget. A very well known insurance company proclaimed that, in view of the proposed concession in relation to insurance premiums, insurance policies would be a more attractive form of investment than formerly. Although the Treasurer (Sir Arthur Fadden) had not announced this proposed concession until about 9 o'clock on the previous night, this quarter-page advertisement, headed in bold type, appeared in a Sydney newspaper -

quote.para: The Government's decision to increase the personal tax. allowance for Life Assurance premiums to £300 per annum, designed to encourage savings and to combat inflation, enables you to take advantage of the most competitive premium rates offered.

speech.para: Where did that knowledge come from?

talk.start.para: - That information was given publicly before the budget was brought down.

- I suggest that it was obtained long before 8 o'clock or 9 o'clock of last Thursday night, for an advertisement of that type and character to appear in the press on the following morning. It is very clear proof of the fact that there was prior knowledge of the contents of this budget.

speech.para: Now, at the outset, as this is an appropriate opportunity to follow this course, let me briefly recite the state of the nation today, after seven years of government by the present occupants of the treasury bench. We find a thoroughly confused Federal Government, presiding amidst a litter of broken promises over a thoroughly confused economy, which is highlighted by the aspects that I shall enumerate. I invite Government senators, if they think that any one of them is wrong, to tell me so as I proceed. They are inflation, vicious taxation, credit restrictions, import restrictions, loss of overseas sterling balances, high interest rates, a weak loan market, contracting export markets, chaos in industrial wage fixation, an embarrassing immigration problem, growing unemployment, shortage of hard currencies, restrictions of foreign exchange, lag in recruitment for the defence forces, and defence forces unready for mobilization. What a record! What a state of the nation; and nobody on the Government side is able to question any one of those elements or facets of the situation.

talk.start.para: - I rise to a point of order. I submit that the remarks of the Leader of the Opposition are grossly out of order, inasmuch as it is an offence against the Standing Orders to interject while a senator is speaking. Senator McKenna should not, therefore, imply that the lack of interjections means acquiescence in his arguments.
- Order! The point of order is not upheld.

- It is quite a refreshing change for me to hear no interjections. I have found Government supporters exceedingly vocal when they have disagreed with me, whether with reason or without it, and it is a most unusual and refreshing experience to find none of my submissions queried. That is the state of the nation that this Government, with Goebbels-like audacity, calls prosperity. That is the extraordinary part of it. 1 hope to deal in some detail with these individual matters as I proceed. At the present stage, I want to comment generally on this sorry spectacle. What an abject confession or failure on the part of a government which began seven years ago with a balanced economy, a balanced budget, a low cost structure, high overseas reserves, and has had the advantage of seven most bountiful seasons throughout the whole of its term! What a record! I put it that failure is not the worst sin. Failure due to incompetence and laziness can be forgiven. I think J. R. Lowell, the poet, expressed perfectly in one line what I wish to convey to the Senate when he said -

speech.para: Not failure but low aim is crime.
I accuse the Government of low aim throughout the whole of its administration. I take that line as my theme in my opening attack on this budget; it is not failure, but low aim that is the crime.

Reviewing the priorities that this Government has established for itself, I say its first priority was to keep itself in office at all costs, even at the cost of its self-respect and its honour. That.I suggest, is a low aim. I refer first of all under that heading to the spate of promises that this Government made to the people and which it broke one after the other, shamelessly andcompletely.It promised to reduce living costs. That was cruel treatment to the pensioners. It promised to reduce living costs rather than increase the amount of payment made to pensioners. It promised to put purchasing value back into the £1. It promised the people of Australia that it would reduce taxation, that it would abolish all restrictive controls by 1952 and that it would abolish the means test. We have heard nothing of that since. It solemnly promised the people of Australia in 1952 that it would impose an excess profits tax. That promise was solemnly made by the Prime Minister in 1950, yet not one thing has been done from that day until now through this period of six years, and that has been the basic cause of inflation, the basic cause of the disbalance and upset in our economy.

My second count against the Government is that it has played politics with the nation's affairs to serve the same low aim of retention of office. I remind the Senate that in the year of the horror budget - 1951-52 - there was imposed upon the people of Australia an extraordinary gloom of taxation to the tune of £209,000.000 in the one year. Then, in 1953, there were remissions of that taxation. Examining the juxtaposition of the remissions and the following Senate election, the reason for the remissions appears very clear. The Government was using the most flexible instrument of economic policy - taxation - simply to play politics on the eve of an election.

In 1954, we saw the phenomenon repeated when, with a House of Representatives election looming, there were more remissions of taxation. Playing upon this same instrument, the Government repeated the phenomenon in another way in 1955, again on the eve of an election. On that occasion, the Government brought out the House of Representatives from this Parliament almost two years ahead of its time, a most extraordinary proceeding explainable only by one reason, namely, that the Government knew it was faced with financial difficulty. It knew that in the immediate future, despite the budget introduced only a few months before, it was about to reimpose enormous taxation - and this without one reference to the people, without one word of warning. This time, without one word to the people, it brought the House of Representatives out and it won an election. What a pity it was that the soothsayer from "Julius

Caesar " was not about at the time to say, " Beware the ides of March ". It was on the ides of March, on 15th March, just three months after this Government was elected, that there came that awful mulct upon the people of Australia to the tune of £115,500,000 a year, when this Government struck at the very people who elected it, not at big business so much but at the individual. It struck at all the things that form part of the individual's .daily life. It struck at his liquor, his tobacco and his petrol, lt certainly imposed disabilities upon car manufacturers and the vendors of cars, but it did increase interest rates for banks. This gave the banks increased profits. Do not let anybody in the Senate imagine that interest rates were not directed at the individual, because the business concerns which take advantage of credit facilities invariably deduct those interest commitments as an allowable deduction for taxation; and, secondly, pass them on in increased costs to the community. Whether it be increases in the costs of goods or services, it is the individual in the Australian community who finally pays that increased charge. That was one more burden that was passed on to the individual.

Then there was the extraordinary clash of opinion between the Prime Minister and the Treasurer of this country at the time when that supplementary budget was brought in on the ides of March. The Prime Minister indicated that it was an anti-inflationary measure. Nobody in this community could accept that statement because, on the face of it, how do you keep costs down by adding to them? As everybody knows, customs duty, excise duty and sates tax, being passed into the manufacture of goods, are passed on by each wholesaler, with each wholesaler's margin of profit on top of it. To-day, we are faced with a sales tax of £130,000,000, and a pay-roll tax of £48,000,000 a year, both those items unquestionably projecting into the cost structure of this country at the very least another £300,000,000. Accordingly, the Prime Minister's statement simply could not be accepted, not even by the man in the street who does not claim to know anything about economics.

The Treasurer put the position quite clearly, following the Prime Minister, when he said the money was wanted to help support State works programmes because of the expected failure of the loan market, and, secondly, because loans to the tune of about £200,000,003 were falling due for conversion during the current financial year and it was expected that they would not be completely converted and that the unconverted part would have to be met in cash and for that reason large funds would be required. I ask the Leader of the Government in the Senate why the people were not told that in the preceding December. Why was not that fact put before them? There was deceit, deception and political trickery about that election and I use that as one of the counts upon which I level the charge that the Government was more concerned about keeping itself in office than about attending to the good of this country.

Now, let me go back to 1954 for a moment and deal with import cuts. The Senate will remember that on 27th September, 1955, following the budget, the Prime Minister made a dramatic statement in the House of Representatives. On that occasion he said -

quote.para: In April, 1954, a large group of items was put on a " no quota restriction " basis, which meant that licences were given for any amount so long as it could be shown that goods were genuinely on order and available. The results were so dramatic that in last October it became necessary to discontinue the no quota restriction system, which had proved a major factor-

speech.para: Mark those words - which had proved a major factor in import pressure, and put the good,", back on a quota basis.

Again, we have that. March madness that has characterized this Government throughout its term. In March it had decided that as from 1st April the lid was taken off for imports. Of course, there was a House of Representatives election coming up shortly. Could that have been merely by strange coincidence? The importers of this country were given a complete licence to import what they liked, and they took advantage of it. The Prime Minister himself had to admit only last year that the results were so dramatic that the Government had to come right back and close down on imports again. But the important point is that the damage was done. That year, we went back to the tune of £256,000,000 in our current account on overseas trade. With capital inflow and loans bolstering the position temporarily, we finally lost £142,000,000 on our cash reserves, abroad. That happened while the Government played politics. That was a wretched thing for a government to do. It is one of the reasons why the Opposition was impelled to move a vote of censure.

I direct attention to another matter in which the Government played politics. In 1954, while it was engaged in this political trickery, and again just before the federal elections of that year, we witnessed the most shameless political stunting over the abortive royal commission that was stimulated by Petrov. His disclosures were not kept within the knowledge of the security service, which could have used them for the purpose of national security, and what was the result? This Government used that royal commission in the most shameless way as a platform for character assassination of its political opponents. What did that cost Australia? The previous year, our trade with Russia was valued at £27,000,000. The upshot of the Petrov commission was that we severed diplomatic relations with Russia and, in the following year, our exports to that country fell to £153,000. Our trade with Russia dropped from £27,000,000 in 1954 to £153,000 in the next year, and in the year just closed our trade with Russia was valued at £20. What were our exports last year? They were merely a few gifts. We sacrificed £27,000,000 a year to enable this Government to play politics, and that at a time when the balance of overseas payments is one of the most crucial problems facing us.

I have driven home the first priority. The second priority of this Government was to build a trade monopoly, and" to serve the interests of powerful business organizations before all else. I suggest that that, too, was a low aim, having regard to other things that the Government should have done. The first matter under this heading was the increase of bank interest rates to a maximum of 6 per cent. That was intended to curb the demand for credit. It is a most absurd proposition for this Government to advance when money is being sought at 15 per cent, and 16 per cent, for purposes to which I shall refer later. While people are paying up to 20 per cent. for money, this Government pretends that an increase of interest rates to 6 per cent, will stem the demand. I remind honorable: senators that this Government sold out itsinterests in Amalgamated Wireless (Australasia) Limited on the eve of the advent of television in Australia.

talk.start.para: - How long ago?

- In the past few years. I am reviewing the history of thisGovernment during its seven years in office. One has to go back a few years to see the pattern of its behaviour emerge clearly, and. that is why I am referring to these matters. The aim was low even then. At the time, we did not know how low it was, but eventshave exposed its objectives. On the very eve of the advent of television, the Government walked out of the field where it might have conditioned the prices for television sets and equipment, and handed the whole field over to private enterprise asa complete monopoly. The Government would not even remain in the field as a. conditioning factor.

speech.para: What happened only recently when plans for. television were near fruition? The Government handed four television stations to the dominating control of four newspapers: organizations that already control communications through the press and radiothroughout Australia, and are now to be given control of the newest and most powerful means of mass communication. The Government has served the interests that I have specified.

What did the' Government do quiterecently? Senator Scott will remember that only in the past few months, the Parliament handed over to private shipping interests of Australia what is, in effect, an absolutemonopoly of all expansion of trade on the coast of Australia for twenty yearsunder an agreement that was signed by this Government. In the process, the Government said to the Commonwealth shipping line: " These are your confines. Stay within them. You cannot even book your own cargo or make your own stevedoring., arrangements ". The Government has given a monopoly to the private shipping, companies of Australia after it failed tosell the Commonwealth shipping line.

talk.start.para: - It did not have the-, courage to sell it.

- The Government could not sell it. The ship-owners were too hungry. They were not even prepared to pay bargain prices; otherwise, the Commonwealth shipping line would have gone to them. The pattern continues. Only recently, the Government handed over the undertaking of the Australian Whaling Commission in Western Australia to the commission's competitors in business without calling public tenders, without disclosing to this Senate the valuations involved in the transaction, and on terms which the purchaser could meet out of profits alone. Those profits are now at the rate of £200,000 a year. The Government also sold the Commonwealth Oil Refineries Limited. That organization was the one listening post this nation had in the vital field of oil. Again, the Government turned down opportunities to go further into that field which is so vital to the nation, and removed the last conditioning factor that it might have had in that field. Practically every gallon of oil we use comes from overseas. It is as vital to this country as air. Ships cannot sail, aeroplanes cannot fly and road transport cannot move without oil, but this Government walked out of a field that is vital to our security and the national economy. Let us consider what was done by this Government in the field of aviation as between Australian National Airways Proprietary Limited and Trans-Australia Airlines. This Government with its own aviation instrumentality, went out of its way to build up its competitor, handing it mails and giving it finance.

speech.para: I claim that I have justified the second count against this Government. Let me turn my attention now to the third and last priority of this Government. I refer to the ordinary average Australian - the pensioners, those on fixed incomes, the mass ot the workers and their families. They are the people who have been put last by this Government in its assessment of values. Those people are Australians. There would be no Australia without them.

talk.start.para: - They are the people who elected this Government to office.

- They are the people who have been deceived by this Government. They are Australians, and the first duty of the Government is to serve their interests and not the interests of big business. The Government has taken advantage of the indifference of the ordinary Australian, his ignorance of economic affairs and his forgetfulness. It relied upon that a great deal.

speech.para: Let us consider how the Government has treated the ordinary Australian. Taxation now runs to the tune of £1,095,000,000 a year. Of that amount, £401,000,000 is obtained by direct income tax charges and £422,000,000 is concealed in indirect taxes. The Chifley Government raised £504,000,000 by taxation in its last year of office. Perhaps some honorable senator will ask what was the relation between taxation and the national income. I may be asked whether it is not a fact that the national income has risen. I say of course it did; but let honorable senators on the Government side work the figures out and ascertain what percentage of the national income this Government is taking in taxation, and what percentage the Chifley Government took in its last year of office. They will be amazed if they do that.

talk.start.para: - Perhaps, Senator McKenna would be amazed if he worked them out.
- I have worked them out.
- Then, perhaps, the honorable senator will quote them.

- I shall not hesitate to quote them. This year, taxes based upon the national income for last year - because we have not this year's figures available - will be 25.5 per cent, of the national income. Taxation for the preceding year was 23.1 per cent. In 1949, during the Chifley regime, the taxation worked out at 22 per cent, of the national income.
- On what figures?

- I have worked out the figures, and the Minister will have an opportunity to check those figures. The next point is that the burden of the supplementary budget through the charges on liquor, tobacco, and petrol, and other charges, has fallen directly upon the ordinary average Australian. High interest rates make their impact upon him in everything that he buys or uses, and I do not forget that it was this Government which, in handing out medical benefits and giving additional hospital benefits, said to the people of Australia, " None of these things are for you unless you are properly insured "; and such insurance costs the family man about £15 a year which he can properly regard as additional taxation imposed on him to attract benefits from this Government for which he has already paid in taxes.

speech.para: Now, let us consider what this budget does for the little man. Television is about to be introduced into Australia. The people have waited for television for six long years under this Government, but when it commences does the Government facilitate their acquisition of television sets? No, it does not, because in this budget it puts a duty of £7 on each cathode tube required in television sets. These tubes have to be replaced regularly, but the Government is putting difficulties in the way of the ordinary person who might be looking forward to getting a television set as cheaply as possible. Let honorable senators consider postal charges. The ordinary Australian, perhaps, writes only a few letters a year, and sends a rare telegram on an important anniversary. Maybe he thinks that these increased charges will not affect him. But the great bulk of the charges are paid by businesses, and the increased charges enter into the costs of those businesses and are passed on to the consumer as extra charges for goods and services. The Australian people should understand that the £5,000,000, or more, of additional postal charges will come directly out of his pocket.

Consider the Government's action in increasing the allowable deduction in respect of education expenses of children from £75 a year to £100 a year for each child. How magnificent that is for the few who will benefit from it! How many of the people of Australia will actually benefit? It is all too clear that the benefit to the people this year will be about £20,000, and approximately £500,000 in a full year. Similar arguments may be applied to the increased deduction allowed in respect of insurance premium. To the present time a deduction of £200 has been allowed, and that has been increased to £300. I ask any honorable senator on the Government side to tell me how many of the wage and salary earners of Australia were in a position to spend £4 a week on insurance premiums, and how many are now in a position to spend £6 a week on them. An ordinary worker on an income of about £14 a week, with a young family, cannot even live at a decent standard if he does not get overtime.

talk.start.para: - Even then his wife would have to go out to work.
- Yes, as Senator Sheehan has said, in many cases the wives of such men have to go out to work.

speech.para: The word-spinning of this Government has evolved a number of new words which cannot be found in the dictionary. They are all - designed to bemuse an ordinary Australian. Unemployment is now " disemployment "; depression is not depression any longer, it is " recession "; and this situation of economic chaos, in which this Government reigns, is called " prosperity ". Now, how lightly must the words of this Government be taken. On 19th October last year the then Minister for the Interior walked into the House of Representatives and announced that as a result of trie Government's decision to practise what it preached, as the Prime Minister had said in his economic statement, capital works expenditure was to be reduced from £104,000,000 by £10,000,000. He said that he had already applied a cut of £4,000,000. Instead of cutting off £10,000,000, or £4,000,000 as the Minister had announced in the House of Representatives, he cut off £2,000,000; and this year he has added £6,000,000 to the figure which, last year, he indicated was the proper sum to be expended on capital works. In other words, he made his statement merely to pretend that something was being done which was not even contemplated. That was mere political trickery.

This Government budgeted to spend £104,000,000, and in order to practise what it preached it stated that it would reduce the sum by £4,000,000. But this year the amount has been increased to £109,000,000. Is that not a condemnation of this Government and an indication that the people can no longer take seriously anything that it says?

talk.start.para: - Has the honorable senator looked at the gallup polls lately?

- Yes, I have. This Government has made the ordinary average Australian pay for the whole of the capital works of the Commonwealth, and most of the capital works of the States, out of his own private pocket. I wonder how many Australians realize that in the seven years that this Government has ruled, the public has had to pay almost £120,000,000 for capital works. They have to pay £ 100,000,000 for Federal works and about £450,000,000 for State works this year. If the loan market had not been disrupted and ruined by the Government allowing inflation to run free, if the Government had not interfered with interest rates and destroyed the confidence of investors, the money required for capital works would have been raised on the loan market and repayment of the debt spread over the taxpayers of the next 53 years, as the cost of capital works always was spread throughout the years prior to the advent of this Government. In the light of those facts, is it any wonder that I charge this Government with low aims towards the ordinary Australian.

speech.para: Now, I shall deal with the outstanding figures of the budget. Last year, taxation was £997,000,000, having increased by £97,000,000. The overall revenue has increased by £99,000,000 and the expenditure by £52,000,000 for the year. Does the Government practise what it preaches in those circumstances? There is to be an overall surplus of £109,000,000, and I have indicated that that will be applied to bolster States works programmes and take care of the deficiency in loan conversions. I ask members of the Government how they think ordinary civilian and war pensioners are likely to regard the fact that although the Government expects to collect this year £1,230,000,000 in revenue and to have a surplus of £109,000,000, nothing is done for them? I ask how they expect the pensioners to react to Sir Frederick Shedden's statement that, tucked away in 21 defence trust accounts at 1st July, 1955, was £98,000,000 while the Government cannot find £1,000,000 to increase civil or military pensions. How does the ordinary Australian regard the fact that there is supposed to be £193,000,000 to the credit of the National Welfare Fund established for the very purpose of building up social services resources, when there is not even £1.000,000 provided in this budget for the pensioners of Australia? How do supporters of the Government expect the workers to regard company profits, and profits made by business organizations, while their wages have been, in most instances, stationary for almost three years? It is interesting to contrast the progress of company profits with the static condition of wages. From September, 1953, to June, 1956, wage rates in federal awards have remained stationary but in exactly the same period of three years the profits of companies rose from £378,000,000 in 1952-53 to £550,000,000 last year. That is an increase of £172,000,000 while wages remained stationary. A total of £120,000,000 was paid out in dividends, an increase from £92,000,000 in 1952-53. An amount of £213,000,000 in undistributed profits was placed in reserves. That was more than the amount paid out in dividends, and did not include secret reserves. Another £29,000,000 of undistributed profits and £187,000,000 paid in tax bring the total to £549,000,000.

talk.start.para: - What about the sums paid out in capital investment?
- I will come to capital later. I am dealing now with certain company profits, but there are many more profits to be mentioned.
- What does the honorable senator mean by secret reserves?

- I will educate the honorable senator later if he wishes. I may mention, however, that one source of secret reserves is the under-statement of stocks and another is the writing off of excessive amounts in depreciation. Those are two items which the honorable senator can think about while 1 tell the Senate about business profits made by the unincorporated bodies during the period when wages were pegged. Their profits rose from £414,000,000 to £520,000,000 in 1955-56.
- Because there were more of them.
- That was an increase of £106,000,000.
- It the honorable senator cited the corresponding figures for wages in an honest way he would get the same result.

- I would get nothing of the kind. These figures disclose the payment of record dividends, and show that record sums were placed in reserves. When the increased profit of £106,000,000 made by unincorporated bodies is added to the profit increase of other companies the total increase over that three-year period is shown to be £278,000,000, but during that whole time the salaries of workers under federal awards were stationary.
- It is no wonder that the people take no notice of the honorable senator's party when he talks such nonsense.

- When the honorable senator has time to think he might consider what is the average wage paid in Australia to-day, and he will then receive a surprise. 1 now wish to discuss overseas balances, and I point out that during the seven years that this Government has been in office it has lost, on current account in overseas trading, £821,000,000. In one year, 1951-52, it lost £579,000,000, and in the last two years £478,000,000. There were, however, offsetting gains in two years. The Government made amends to some extent by borrowing overseas and by securing the investment of overseas capital in Australia, but both those courses are highly dangerous. They are all right on short term to improve the balance of payments and to prevent too great a crash of our London sterling balances, but they have long-term effects which could be disastrous for this country. I invite any responsible member of the Government to examine an article published by its own Bureau of Agricultural Economics in April last. lt pointed out that North American investments in Australia had grown to such an extent and the rate of profit made in this country on. those investments had expanded so vastly that, as the article points out -

quote.para: This rate of increase indicates that within a few years, a decision by American companies to repatriate profits as dividends instead of ploughing them back could absorb the whole of Australia's dollar income and force the imposition of even more drastic restrictions upon imports of developmental equipment for Australian rural industries and manufacturers.

speech.para: Even with all the bolstering of the balance of payments position, two years ago Australia lost £142,000,000 in hard cash and £73,000,000 last year. Honorable senators must remember that on all money borrowed overseas interest must be paid, and on all overseas capital invested here, dividends are payable, so that the Government has, in effect, been mortgaging the future. As pointed out in this very thoughtful article, circulated by the Government's own bureau, there is a warning for the Government about the long-term effects of its policies.

The Treasurer (Sir Arthur Fadden), in his budget speech, said that the underlying problem was a conflict between the desire for development - including the growth of population - on the one hand, and the efforts of the people to achieve higher standards of consumption and better living standards by the people. But he overlooked one vital element - that is, the matter of defence and security. My colleague, Senator Byrne, in a brilliant speech recently delivered, posed perfectly the dilemma into which the Communist countries have forced the democracies. He pointed out that in all countries to-day there is a conflict over the use of resources for development, defence, security, consumption and standards of living. The Communist countries trampled remorselessly upon the individual and his aspirations in favour of security and the development of their economies. When one follows the trend in this country, however, one finds the same pattern, lt is the individual here who is asked to sacrifice his standard of living and to carry the whole burden of halting inflation. It is not the profiteer who is asked to do that, however, but the worker and the pensioner. The profiteer is allowed to run free. There is this difference between the position of Australia and that of the Communist countries: Although they trampled on the individual, at least they have made some show of success about their development and their security. They have gone bull-headed for those two objectives. Australia, however, has failed in all three. Our development is lagging in regard to homes, schools, and hospitals and our roads are in a chaotic condition. Who can be proud of the present stage of Australia's development? As to defence, I remind honorable senators that the Public Accounts Committee pilloried the Department of Air over the way it had bungled its accounts and finance. Sir Frederick Shedden, the secretary of the Department of Defence, stated to the Public Accounts Committee, " We are not ready for mobilization; we were not in 1953 ". Sir

Lawrence Wackett, the chairman of the Aircraft Corporation, put the position plainly in one of yesterday's newspapers. He indicated, although he did not use these words, that although a mission from this Government had been abroad for eighteen months to determine what new types of aircraft would be put on the assembly line, the corporation is still without a decision' as to what is to replace the type now going out of production; and even if that advice were available now, the corporation would not be ready, when the last Sabre comes off the line, to put the new one on. In other words, we are utterly unprepared and have failed in our defences - bungling and lagging.

talk.start.para: - Except in spending money.

- We are spending large sums to make the Australian public think that something is being done whereas nothing tangible is being done. Sir Frederick Shedden, the Secretary of the Department of Defence, exposed the fact that £98,000,000 is tucked away in trust funds for defence purposes. But there is nothing for the pensioners! I have mentioned these things to the Government year after year. I have directed attention to the strategic stores and equipment account, which year after year has contained the amount of £48,000,000, to the Korea operations fund which contains £10,000,000 and to the defence equipment and supply account ' in which there is a balance of £20,000,000. Those were the balances in those funds at 30th June last and they have been added to by many more items.

speech.para: I say to the Government that its policy of laisser faire - leave things alone and they will sort themselves out - would be adopted only by an individual who would say that the whole miracle of the universe had evolved from inanimate and unintelligible matter. It just will not happen that way. Nothing will cure inflation and right the economy unless the Government will grasp the nettle and take the proper steps to do so. There must be federal prices control of interest rates. Men seeking war service homes have to wait for their finance but have projects immediately before them for which they are paying 15 per cent. to 20 per cent, interest for financial accommodation to tide them over until they can obtain approval of their loans.

talk.start.para: - How many of them?
- The sharks are there, and they are not halted by this Government.
- How many of them?
- I do not know, but I know that ex-servicemen have been asked to pay that interest rate; and they are paying it.
- Produce them.

- I could produce the estate agents who told me about it; and I will refer the honorable senator to one very large insurance company in Sydney which can produce to him notices of second mortgages at 20 per cent, interest. That is the kind of black market this Government is encouraging. It is the worst kind of black market - in money - the very life-blood of trade, commerce and industry. There might have been black markets when controls were running out under a Labour government, but at least they were illegal. We had running on indictment fines up to £5,000 and gaol for five years; but what has this Government done? It has a black market in import licences - a disgrace in recent years; and there is the worst and most pernicious type of black market in money which is actually fostered and sponsored by this Government.

speech.para: Unquestionably, a situation as difficult as we have in Australia to-day will not sort itself out. Unless something positive is done, it will drift and drift. The Labour party believes in facing a positive position with positive action. After all is said and done, we have proved that it is effective. While Labour was in office for eight years we had controls and although there were the most terrific inflationary pressures throughout that time due to war expenditure and due to many people not having access to the things they wanted day by day, homes and the rest, we were able to hold costs down during the whole of those eight years. During that time, the cost of living rose only £1 16s. in eight years: but during the six and a half years of this Government's office the cost of living alone - I am not including the £1 that was added to the basic wage in December. 1950 - has risen by £5 lis. What an inglorious record! That is under Liberal-Country party rule. Let me indicate how the cost of living rose and how the Government did nothing to halt it. In 1950 it rose by 13s., in 1951 by 38s., in 1952 by 31s., and in 1953 by 8s. lt fell by ls. in 1954, and then rose by lis. in 1955. Now, it is off again in a glorious gallop in 1956. What an inglorious record in trying to halt inflation which the Treasurer tells us in his speech is now probably at its most difficult stage. After six years of what he termed a real struggle to halt it he has got exactly nowhere at all.

I desire to say a word or two on social services. I had hoped to devote some real time to this subject. Throughout the last year the cost of living has risen at the rate of 15s. a week, judged by the C series index. That, in turn, has lowered the spending power of pensioners throughout Australia. They have just come through a wet, cold winter. Eighty per cent, of them have no income other than their pension. On £4 a week many of them, unless they are living with relatives, have to find food, clothing; warmth and shelter, and I say that the plight of pensioners throughout Australia to-day is just shocking. Tens of thousands of them are cold, hungry and homeless, and many of them lonely. It is a terrific plight and this Government has been brutal in handling all this money, all this revenue and having a surplus of £109,000,000 for purposes that it may not be required to anything like the extent that is suggested, and yet is not finding even £1,000,000, let alone £20.000,000, for pensioners. I know that some honorable senators on the Government side have made representations to the Government for pension increases, but they have been overborne. I challenge the majority of honorable senators on the Government side who have upheld the budget in this respect to stand up and justify that position. With a surplus of £109,000,000, with reserves tucked away, with a revenue for the year of £1,230.000,000, not £1,000,000 is to be found for pension increases! Every member of the Government party should be ashamed at this inhuman and brutal treatment of people who have served this country well.

Then there is child endowment. What has the Government done for the family? It has allowed child endowment to remain at 10s. a week since 1948, except for the addition of 5s. for the first child. That 5s. to-day would not even buy a decent sized apple a day for a child, let alone a pint of milk. This Government has seriously ignored their desperate plight.

I should like to say a word about unemployment. The Minister for National Development (Senator Spooner) cited figures on unemployment when asked for them the other day by referring to the number receiving unemployment benefit. He pointed out that in Australia on 18th August there were 10,416 persons drawing unemployment benefit. He indicated that that represented only one-third of 1 per cent, of the total work force. When that is left there, it presents a completely wrong picture of the unemployment situation in Australia, because in the bulletins issued month by month by the Department of Labour and National Service it appears that the number of people who have notified the department of the fact that they are out of work i'.nd have not been placed was 16,266 as on 1st January last and at 30th June the number was 31,517.

talk.start.para: - At what date was that?

- That was at 29th June, as the honorable senator will find if he looks at the statement. I have it in my mind that, in the interim, the figure has grown to 35,000. But whether it is 31,000 or 35,000 is not relevant to my argument. I think it is a tragedy, to which every parliamentarian should address himself, if there is even one person in this country - let alone 30,000 - who is able and willing to work but cannot obtain a job. It is a serious matter not only for the individuals themselves, but also for their families.
- Thirty thousand out of how many - 2,750,000?

- What do statistics matter to a man who is out of work and is hungry? The Minister need not start calling out loudly. The plight of a person who is unemployed cannot be expressed adequately, or at all, in terms of statistics. [Extension of time granted.] I must discard many subjects that I should have liked to talk upon, but I thank the Senate for the opportunity to continue. I regret that 1 am not able to traverse the whole question of wage policy, including the divergence between Federal and State awards, and the recent abortive conference summoned by the Acting Prime Minister (Sir Arthur Fadden) and attended by the State Premiers. I merely wish to comment that 1 think the Government must . accept its responsibility for the wage disparity and consequently for the difficulty in which it finds itself. It has added to the cost of living by reducing or cutting out food subsidies. No less than ls. 6id. per lb. on tea has gone into the C series index since the Government cut down the subsidy on this commodity. Butter and cheese have gone up for the same reason.
- Thank goodness beer still goes down!
- That is a truly Treasury outlook, may I say. I pass to my concluding matter. The Treasurer, in the course of his budget speech, said -

quote.para: Locked away in this vast land of ours are resources capable of enlarging our export potential and diminishing our need for imports.

speech.para: I point out, in particular to the Minister for National Development, that if this Government has any imagination at all, it has a vast opportunity to explore and exploit these resources. Oil is the great thing. I have remarked already to-night how vital it is, and I am not going to traverse the subject again. I merely say that one would expect the Government itself to be leading the band in the search for oil, a commodity upon which the very life of this country hinges.' I say that it is the duty of this Government to comb every square mile of Australia, and not leave the oil prospecting companies to proceed at their leisure, and within their limited capacity to search in various places. I suggest that this is a matter in which the Government should give a lead. Let us have a look at how much of a lead it has given. A glance at the Estimates will show that in a year in which £1,230,000,000 is to be received, this Government will spend £129,000 on oil search surveys. This amount will be made available to the Bureau of Mineral Resources in Australia. It represents a niggardly .0001 per cent, of the estimated receipts- for the year. I am commending to the Government the thought of Sir Arthur Fadden; let it expand the thought imaginatively. Let us find oil, if there are oil deposits in Australia, because there in one stroke we will resolve our balance of payments problem- We import something like £90,000,000 worth of petrol and petroleum products annually. If we could find our own supplies in Australia we could get to the position where we could, perhaps, export petroleum products, and the whole balance of payments problem would resolve itself. There would also be a very real impact upon the cost structure in Australia.

talk.start.para: - Have we not already exported £9,000,000 worth this year?
- Yes, we have exported some but we had to import crude oil in order to do that.
- Is research not going on?

- Yes, research is being conducted by private companies, but there, is not adequate research by the Government. Instead of expending a paltry £129,000 in a year on oil research, it should be expending millions of pounds. I think that there is a complete lack of leadership in this field, as well as in other aspects of government activity.

speech.para: I conclude by saying that all that I have said more than justifies the censure motion that I have moved against this Government. It came in as a government of promises, and to-day it is a government of excuses. It has dismally failed Australia in every sphere of finance and the economy. As I have indicated, it is a government of low aim. It is a government that is incompetent and lazy. It has failed to provide leadership for the Australian nation. I say that the Menzies-Fadden Administration is an expensive luxury that this nation can no longer afford.

talker.role: Attorney-General and Minister for the Navy
talker.name: O'SULLIVAN, Neil
Senator O'SULLIVAN

talk.start.para: . - I am quite sure that those of us who have been listening here, and those who have been listening to the broadcast could be pardoned for failing to realize, after listening to the Leader of the Opposition (Senator McKenna), that a budget is a statement of the finances of a country and the Government's programme for the year ahead. We have put down specific and definite problems and propositions, and we have invited the Opposition to debate them. But nothing was said by the Leader of the Opposition, in real terms, to-night about the budget. There was a lot of appeal to the ignorant and the uninformed. There was rather mean play, I think, upon the needs of those in poor and necessitous circumstances. On an occasion like this, and in the circumstances that our country faces, I think we are entitled as a government to expect from the Leader of the Opposition some constructive suggestions. In all fairness, I cannot recollect one such suggestion in the speech to which we have just listened. The whole hour, plus some minutes, was spent almost entirely, playing upon the misfortunes and the misery of those in poor circumstances, and in preying upon the ignorance of the uninformed in regard to other matters. I hoped that I would have some reasonable argument to answer, and that out of the ensuing debate would emerge something of benefit to our country and to the people whom this Parliament serves. In that hope I have been dis- -.. appointed,

speech.para: Senator McKenna stated that there had been leakages of budget information. He went on to say that one of the vital leakages was that there was "going to be an increase in postal charges. Is it suggested that people have been going around buying up postage stamps so that they could traffic in them? Let us consider the matter. The Leader of the Opposition said that there was a leakage of the information that postal charges would rise. Generally speaking, of course, budget leakages are regarded as shockingly nefarious, and are to be deplored. Information is disclosed for the purpose of enabling somebody to profit by trafficking in commodities the price of which will rise as a result of the budget. Fortunately, there has been very little if any of that in this country. The gigantic contribution made by the Leader of the Opposition (Senator McKenna) to the welfare of our country is that there has been a leakage in regard to postal charges! I hope his children have not been buying up stamps, cornering the market before the price goes up.

Then, he suggests there was another leakage. It is tragic to think that this is the type of contribution the Leader of the Opposition should make. He informs us that there was a leakage that there was going to be an increase in the allowances made in income tax for life assurance. Where could there be any trafficking in connexion with that? Who would profit by any foreknowledge of that? Whether there was any foreknowledge I do not know, but, if there was, who could profit as a result? It may have been just speculation that led to the suggestion because, over the years, even during the time of the Labour Government, representations have been made from time to time that for those who are self-employed there should be higher allowances for contributions made to life assurance. But, the point is: Who is trafficking in their own life assurance policies?

Then, the Leader of the Opposition goes on to refer to broken promises. He did not give any specific details of promises that were broken. On the contrary, I think he very unfairly insinuated that instead of reducing taxation we have increased it. . He knows as well as anybody else who pays taxation knows, that the rate of taxation has been reduced considerably since we have been in power. In the many budgets that we have introduced, I think that in only two of them have we. failed to make substantial reductions in the rate of taxation. It is true that we collect considerably more revenue by way of taxation. For instance, last year the national income rose to £4,312,000,000, an increase of 6i per cent, over that of the previous year; but, as against that, wages rose by £209,000,000, or 9 per cent. I do not complain about the fact that wages rose, but the point is that whereas our national income rose by 6i per cent., wages rose by 9 per cent. The Leader of the Opposition was not quite fair in his comment in that respect, because he knows that during the last days of the Chifley Government, the basic wage was in the vicinity of £4 14s. or £4 15s., whereas the average wage paid to-day is in the vicinity of £17. The basic wage to-day is £ 14-odd, but the average wage paid throughout the Commonwealth is in the vicinity of £17. Another thing that must be borne in mind is that since the end of the war our population has increased by something of the order of 2,000,000. That being so, it is natural that our wages bill should go up, that our factory bills should increase, and that our professional earnings should be greater. More people are earning and, therefore, more are paying tax. In those circumstances, it is only natural that the amount collected by way of taxation should increase. But that was not the point the Leader of the Opposition made. I feel that he attempted to mislead the people into believing that we are paying a higher rate of taxation. The fact is that we are paying a lower rate of taxation. Our promise to reduce taxation has been faithfully and repeatedly fulfilled in successive budgets.

Then the Leader of the Opposition mentioned restrictions. There was no country so tied and restricted, no country so hogtied by restrictions as was Australia when the angry disillusioned people of Australia threw the Chifley Government out of office an December, 1949. We have progressively wiped off restriction after restriction which we inherited from the socialist government. Perhaps, we were a little over-optimistic because at that time we did not know the tremendous heritage of misfortune that was ours as the result of seven years of unbroken socialist rule. Since that time, rationing !has gone, coupon tickets have disappeared and petrol rationing has been abolished. "We have fulfilled our promises to remove restrictions. We have not seen a ration book since 1950. We have not seen a queue of any sort, apart from places of amusement, since 1950. Those are some of the promises that we made and which we have fulfilled. It is true that we have had to reintroduce import restrictions; but certainly not to anything like the same extent as obtained during the time of the Chifley Government. They are re-introduced now purely for the purpose of protecting outoverseas balances, and we hope that they will be of a temporary nature.

The Leader of the Opposition alleged that we have broken promises in connexion with immigration, but he did not go into details. He did not say that we are bringing in too many immigrants or that we are not bringing in enough, nor did he say whether we are bringing in the wrong types. He merely made the sweeping statement that the Government has broken its promises in connexion with immigration. Tt is very difficult to answer so general an allegation. The immigration policy of this country has been one of the greatest factors contributing to its development since the war. So far as I knew, it was a policy common to both sides of the House. It was launched initially by the Labour party, much to its credit, and I was under the impression that Labour was strongly in favour of immigration still, that it was, thank goodness, one of those items of policy which has risen above and transcends party political considerations in debate. This Government is very proud of its immigration policy and the contribution it has made to the development of Australia.

Then, the Leader of the Opposition made the broad sweeping remark that we are short of hard currency trade, and he implied that somehow or other that is tied up with a broken promise. He did not say in what respect a promise has been broken in this direction, but he knows that our trade with hard currency countries is freer to-day than it ever was under the socialist government that reigned until 1949. Then, he said that we have broken our promise in connexion with defence. As a former Minister, he should know that in the last year of the Chifley Government's term of office the defence vote was £.39,000,000. 1 remind him that the defence vote this year is £190,000,000. Never in the history of Australia in peace-time has our country been in a better defence position.

talk.start.para: - We query that.

- Of course the Labour party queries it. There has been some suggestion that we are not on a war footing. No freedom-loving people, in a time of peace,' is ever on a war footing or ready for immediate mobilization. No country in the free world is ever. ready for immediate mobilization during peace-time. It is not the policy of free people to be always on a war footing. As a peace-loving people in an era of peace, we are in pretty good shape. The situation of our Navy, Army and Air Force in an era of peace has never been better. It K certainly inconceivably better than it was when we inherited the reins of government from the' socialists in 1949.
- We built up Manus Island and they gave it away.
- How the Labour Opposition has the temerity to stand up in this chamber and talk about: defence really bewilders a tolerant chap like myself.

speech.para: During World War II. , the Americans spent £100,000,000 on Manus Island. It. was the greatest bastion of freedom in the Pacific; greater and bigger than Singapore.

When the war ended, the United States of America offered to continue to man and maintain Man us Island while allowing us free use of it. A little Australian, who was then in charge of our external affairs, told the United States to get out, and would not even negotiate on Manus Island. It has taken a long time for us to rebuild our prestige in the eyes of America. Thank goodness, under the enlightened and intelligent leadership of the Prime Minister (Mr. Menzies), Australia now stands very high in the esteem of the United States and the rest of the world. That status has been achieved in spite of the way in which the Americans' offer on Manus Island was turned down. When this Government was first elected to office, one Australian sergeant and a few natives were on Manus Island looking after the remnants of what had been the greatest bastion of freedom in the Pacific.

Senator McKenna referred to social services and what this Government did to help those who are in need. It is most unfair - I will go further and say that it is very cruel - to use an occasion such as this to bad persons who are necessitous and in poor circumstances to think that, if only a Labour government were in power, their worries would be over and Father Christmas would walk among them once more. There is nothing more distasteful than an attempt to capture popular esteem by dwelling on the needs and hardships of the poor.

These attacks are not new. They have been made on the occasion of each budget ever since this Government was elected to office. As the Minister for National Development (Senator Spooner) has said quite aptly, the pensioners prefer to trust us rather than the Labour party with its specious and shallow promises. After all, this Government is not doing badly by them,' and they are not doing badly by us. During the last year of office of the Chifley socialist government, the amount distributed in social services benefits was about £82,000,000. This year, we are providing for an expenditure on those services totalling £226,000,000. That, in itself, indicates that we are not unmindful of the needs of the poor and our obligations to them. 1 was particularly interested in the statements by the Leader of the Opposition in connexion with customs tariffs. They are imposed pursuant to reports received from the Tariff Board, an independent tribunal which meets openly and takes evidence for and against increases of duties.
