As a result of recommendations by the Tariff Board, I am proud to say that this Government has increased customs duties for the purpose of protecting and encouraging worth-while and efficient Australian secondary indus-. tries. If the Leader of the Opposition is implying that the Labour party is not in favour of protecting Australian industries, I invite honorable senators on the Opposition side who support that proposition to stand and say so. We are prepared to protect efficient Australian industries to the extent recommended by the Tariff Board, but if the Australian Labour party is not in favour of assistance, protection and encouragement for efficient Australian industries, the Australian public should know where the Opposition stands in that connexion.

In the course of his meandering address, the Leader- of the Opposition said that the Government had more or less sold its soul so that it could remain in office at any price. I remind the honorable senator that we do not keep ourselves in office. We have been elected by the enlightened, intelligent people of Australia, who have put us in office on four occasions - in 1949, 1951, 1 953 and 1 955. I have no doubt that when we go to the people of Australia again, they will return us with an even bigger majority.

The Leader of the Opposition, in a shot out of the blue, referred to what he termed the " abortive royal commission on Petrov". Abortive? I think it was most fruitful. The free people of the world believe that, also. The free governments of the world have expressed their appreciation of the assistance they obtained through the commission. I do not understand how the Leader of the Opposition could call it abortive. I do not know what it has to do with the budget, either, except that he said that after diplomatic relations with Russia were broken off, our trade with that country fell from £27,000,000 to next to nothing. That is quite true within a few pounds. Our trade with Russia, before diplomatic relations were broken off. totalled about £27,000,000, but the Leader of the Opposition did not go back a year, and say that the purchases by Russia from Australia in that year totalled £600,000. That shows that the existence or lack of diplomatic relations has nothing whatever to do with trade. If Russia wants our commodities it will buy them. If it does not want them, it will not buy. It is sheer nonsense to suggest that Russia buys from us because it likes us.

talk.start.para: - Russia has been buying through continental agents.

- Of course it has. The Leader of the Opposition began to talk about the increase in the bank rate of interest, but he did not continue with that theme, and I cannot follow him further. I do not know whether he is in favour of an increase or a reduction in the bank rate. In the general scheme of things, money is worth what persons who are not over-anxious to borrow will pay to a person who is not over-anxious to lend. I am amazed to learn that, under a Labour government in New South Wales, which has complete and absolute power to control the rate of interest within that State, the shocking rate of 20 per cent, on mortgages is allowed. That is permitted by a Labour government. It would never happen under a Liberal government.

speech.para: The Leader of the Opposition suggested that there had been something in the nature of nepotism or skullduggery in the Government's handling of television licences. 1 should like the Opposition to know that this Government's television legislation was brought down after a most exhaustive inquiry by a royal commission, which was widely representative and completely non-party. Our legislation on television is a model that the rest of the world could well follow. These little points of misrepresentation, these half-truths, which are just as bad as a complete mis-statement, should not be put forward in the way that has been adopted by the Opposition.

We are accused of having handed over the assets of the Government's whaling undertaking to the Nor' West Whaling Company Limited. Let me inform honorable senators that we handed over those assets for a jolly good price; indeed, the highest pries obtainable. After all, we are in government to govern and not to trade.

Moreover, we are not here to engage in trade and lose the people's money. To suggest that we lost £200,000 a year in handing over the whaling station is not a fair proposition. Although the whaling commission may have been making £200,000 a year, or perhaps more, about half that sum will come back to us in taxes. That, of course, was not mentioned by Senator McKenna. If all that Senator McKenna can find to accuse this Government of after it has been seven years in office, is a matter of the whaling station - and a few other minor matters - all I can say is that ours is a better government than I thought it was. After we have been governing for seven years, Senator McKenna has not found one substantial charge to level against us. That is praise, indeed, from the Opposition.

Reference was made to the sale of the Commonwealth's shares in the Commonwealth Oil Refineries Limited. That company was formed after World War I. when the late W. M. Hughes was Prime Minister, in order to attempt to make Australia independent of overseas sources for refined oil. But the amount of oil that Commonwealth Oil Refineries Limited refined up to the time the Government sold its shares in it was infinitesimal. Indeed, it would probably fit into one or two petrol bowsers; it was not a real factor in solving our refined oil problem. The company consequently became merely a vendor of oil and the owner of petrol bowsers in cities, towns and villages throughout Australia. If the Australian Government is going to peddle oil round the country, why should it not open a book shop, a hat shop or a tailor's shop, and go into the retail business properly? Indeed, why should it not apply for a fruit-barrow licence in Sydney and one or two in Melbourne?

talk.start.para: - And go into the motor car business.

- That is so. Senator McKenna did not point out to the people who might have be~n listening to him that during the term of office of this Government more than £100,000,000 has been spent in Australia by oil companies in building refineries, and that this country will soon be in the happy position of exporting refined oil and of casing to import it. Moreover, the refining of oil is now in the hands of trained oil experts and not in the hands of politicians or public servants.
- The . Queensland Labour Government once owned a fish shop in which it sold the dearest fish in Brisbane.

- Yes. Senator McKenna complained that this Government, although the owner of Trans-Australia Airlines, has helped its competitor, Australian National. Airways Proprietary Limited, to survive. 1 would be quite satisfied if throughout my life my most heinous crime was that of helping a competitor. That is not a sin which would weigh very heavily upon my conscience. Of course, we have helped Australian National Airways Proprietary Limited to survive. We believe that monopolies are bad, and that government monopolies are probably the worst of all. We are happy to encourage a little competition, although the people own TransAustralia Airlines. Monopolies are not in the best interests of the people, and as we serve the people I hope that Australian National Airways Proprietary Limited will continue to be allowed to survive and remain in competition with the government-owned airline. Out of that competition a better service will emerge to the benefit of the people of this country; and it is a function of good government to serve the people.

speech.para: Another most unfair approach made by the Leader of the Opposition was along the line that there are people in want, and whether it is their own fault or somebody else's does not matter. There are people who could be more comfortably situated than they are at present. Senator McKenna suggested that there is £98,000,000 tucked away in trust funds for defence, and other millions of pounds tucked away for social services. As a former Minister, he knows very well that this Government cannot go to a safe or strongroom and take out that money, because those funds are merely book entries; and the suggestion that we can put our hands on hundreds of millions of pounds and hand it out to alleviate distress is sheer and utter nonsense. It is worse than that; it is a cruel joke to play on those who need further help, which it is beyond the power of governments to give to them, to allow them to believe that we can get the money but that we are indifferent to their plight and will not bother about them. I repeat that the funds referred to by Senator McKenna are purely book entries.

A suggestion has been made that prices control will solve most, if not all, the economic ills with which we are afflicted. The Labour party should know that that is not true, because it tried prices control and suffered under that system. I am not prepared to resist entirely the proposition that prices control cannot do anything.

talk.start.para: - Does not this Government agree to selective prices control?
- I am making this speech; Senator Kennelly may speak later.
- But the honorable senator favours selective prices control.

- Senator Kennelly is getting ahead of me; he must have been reading my notes. I do not reject in its entirety the proposition that prices control is an ameliorating factor if it is selective and wisely applied and administered. But an overall prices control, although it may soften certain instances of economic difficulty, will not solve anything. There is only one answer to shortages, and that is the production of more goods and services. In the past, some honorable senators opposite have advocated that we should not go short of money, that we should go to the printing presses and turn out currency and issue bank credit. Whether Senator Kennelly agrees with that proposition or not, he will be able to say later; but that solution has been propounded by the Opposition in the past, and I have no doubt that it will be put forward again.
- The honorable senator is anticipating our speeches.

- No, I know the Opposition too well. The production of more money, more notes, more pieces of paper, will not add one box of matches to our national wealth. Only work and the production of goods and services will get us out of any future inflationary difficulties. I hope that no overseas investor or prospective investor has been listening to the debate to-night, because I have never heard such an apostle of gloom as the Leader of the Opposition appeared to be. "We shall all be ruined ", was his attitude. There was not one bright spot in our economy, either ahead of us or behind us, according to the honorable senator. That is a very poor advertisement for our country. Investors overseas regard Australia as the best and safest place in the world in which to invest their money. The hundreds of millions of pounds which have flowed into Australia, and are still flowing in from overseas for permanent investment, are a tribute to the soundness of our economy.

speech.para: Most of the difficulties that we are experiencing to-day are due to the fact that we are developing so rapidly in comparison with our limited resources of manpower and materials. We need more of both. The printing of paper money will not solve our problems. It would make the inflationary spiral more dangerous and devastating than anything else could possibly do. What we need in Australia - and in this the Opposition, with its undoubted influence among the trade unions could help the Government, because the Government has great confidence in the enlightened trade union movement - is co-operation to obtain the best results from man-power and material. If that is done, every one will benefit. The Government does not want to make a bigger cake merely for the purpose of getting a larger slice for itself. There is only one way in which we can get a bigger cake, that is by everybody contributing to the making of it and then being given a fair slice from it. I say again that the Opposition could use its undoubted influence with the trade union movement to assist in this direction.

talk.start.para: - I wish the Government had made provision in the budget for that to be done.

- The Government has done so. Senator Kennelly had given me a glimmer of hope that he had reformed, but such an interjection causes him to slip back to where he was before in my political regard. Making provision to spend money without tangible results will not halt the inflationary spiral.
- The proposed expenditure on the St. Mary's project has not been reduced by much.

- I shall deal with that matter in the discussion on next year's budget. I hope that the people of Australia who may have been listening to Senator McKenna will not be infected or influenced by the story of gloom and despair that he has told. Rather would I pin my faith to statements such as those made by W. S. Robinson and W. S. Smith, who stated recently in the press that Australia was never in a more prosperous condition than at present, and that a glorious future for it was written in the skies.

talker.role: Leader of the Anti-Communist Labour Party
talker.name: COLE, George
Senator COLE

talk.start.para: . - I have listened with interest to the speeches of Senator McKenna and Senator O'sullivan, but I could not get a lead from the speech of Senator O'sullivan because it was simply an answer to the propaganda speech of Senator McKenna. The speech of Senator McKenna made me rather afraid that an election would be held as soon as this budget is passed or rejected. One point in his speech to which I wish to refer is that concerning the Petrov commission, and a second is the loss of £27,000,000 in exports to Russia. Most of that amount was accounted for by the cessation of wool sales to that country, and all I can say is that £27,000,000 was a very cheap price at which to get rid of it.

speech.para: The budget is unimaginative, because it contains no overall plan to safeguard the economic future of Australia. It is depressing, because the burden of holding the economy together bears too heavily on the underprivileged and lower-income groups. It is ineffective because strong measures have not been taken to protect our economy against the undesirable activities of vested interests. A better budget could have been presented if it had been based - and now I, too, enter the propaganda field - on the platform put forward by my party at the last election.

I shall give the Senate a summary of the points of my party's platform, which the present Government was asked to follow for the betterment of Australia. First of all, we asked for decisive and resolute control of banking and monetary measures for the balanced development of Australia. That has not been apparent in this budget. The next point was a programme of government expenditure on a level commensurate with labour resources. That does not mean that the labour resources were too great or too small. At the present time, there is a hint of unemployment in the country, and the Government must use its funds to provide employment on national works. The third point was a priority system for projects, with emphasis on decentralization. This is most important, and because the Government is the controller of the public purse, it must insist on a proper order for public works, even within a State. Other points were the development of export industries by market research, marketing credits and sales promotion schemes in Australia and overseas; action against exorbitant hire-purchase profits; stabilization schemes to ensure adequate returns for primary producers; and correction of one-sided features of the Ottawa agreement. To its credit the Government has been dealing with that matter. My party advocated also priority in man-power, finance and materials to basic industries such as power, iron and steel, engineering, building, transport and agriculture. Next was provision of funds for land settlement. It is most important to make certain that funds for land settlement are used to the best possible advantage. We advocated also the encouragement of the small businessman and shopkeeper as against big business and monopolies; the reduction of indirect taxation, including the abolition of sales tax; and excess profits to be made available to workers by profit sharing. That would greatly relieve the industrial unrest that is disturbing the country at the present time. Finally, we advocated a system of automatic adjustment of wages in accordance with cost-of-living changes.

That programme could have been followed by this Government. If it had been, I should not have had to make the statement concerning the budget which I made in my opening remarks. What is our criticism of this Government's budget? We believe that the Treasurer and his advisers desire to keep the national economy stable, but that they are doin« little or nothing about it. Just like Mr. Micawber, they are waiting for something to turn up and hoping that things will right themselves. Such a policy offers a very poor prospect to those who are the chief victims of the present inflationary trend, namely, the pensioner and the family man.

Pensions have been dealt with to-night and 1 assume that throughout the whole of this debate they will be dealt with at great length I remember standing in this chamber and advocating, that pensions should be taken out of the real-n of "arty politics. The Government did nothing about that, so once again we must deal with pensions in the party political arena. I still advocate that an independent tribunal should be set up to determine the true needs of the pensioners. The Public Service commissioners and other advisers inform the Government that a certain amount of money is needed for increases in salaries. Such a tribunal could perform a similar task in respect of pension rates. If the independent tribunal found that the pensioners should receive a certain sum of money, it would then be the Government's duty to find that sum.

A few weeks ago I made a trip overseas. In Formosa I was encouraged to observe a philosophy of life which, I believe, has been lost in Australia. In Formosa, parents are the most important units of family lite, especially when they grow old. As they are looked after by their children and are given the best, the Government does not need to make provision for them; that is the responsibility of their children. That is a philosophy or way of life that is now unknown in Australia. It is a pity that we could not follow along those lines. It seems that we have reached a stage at which our own material well-being is uppermost and we demand that the pensioners virtually become wards of the State. That is our outlook, and if the Government is not going to do anything about the suggestion I made for the setting-up of a tribunal of the kind I have indicated and thus take pensions out of the realm of party politics, we must live up to our responsibility.

Not so very long ago we increased our own salaries. We were justified in so doing, but it is a very poor thing to increase our own salaries and then, in this budget, fail to give additional aid to the pensioners. I appeal to the Government - and it is not yet too late - to take into consideration the lot of the pensioners. Honorable senators know as well as I do of the sad stories of the plight of pensioners that have been printed in the press and which we know to be true. Because of our philosophy of life, the pensioners are left to fend for themselves, and they cannot do so on £4 a week. Inflation exists, costs are going up, and I should have expected that in this budget at least some little crumb of comfort would have been given to the pensioners. But they have received nothing.

I issue a warning to the Government. It is vital that these people be given some help. Otherwise, the budget should be referred back to another place, and 1 hope that it will be. 1 am sure that if it is, members of .the House of Representatives, and the Treasurer in particular, will do something to increase pensions and help these people.

One matter upon which I congratulate the Government is its attitude towards institutions for these old people. The Government has done a very good job in helping private institutions and those run by religious organizations to look after aged and sick people. The Government has done a great job in that respect, but it must do something more practical. The grave indictment of the Government as far as this budget is concerned is that it has done little or nothing for pensioners at all.

I should like to deal with child endowment. We believe that the family man in Australia must be looked after. It is essential that he have a reasonable standard of living. The single man receives the same salary as a married man does, but the married man has a greater responsibility, especially if he has a number of children. There is one way only in which we can raise the standard of the family man and that is by increasing child endowment. In 1948, a family man with four children received an additional 25.2 per cent, of the basic .wage to help him meet his extra responsibilities. In this year, a family man with four children receives only about 12.1 per cent, of the basic wage in endowment, or less than one-half of what he received in 1948. The extra needs of the family man can only be met by child endowment. I advocate here to-night the bringing in of a scheme to help the family man. As we all know, the maintenance of family life is important to Australia. At least, it safeguards this country from the inroads of communism.

My party believes that endowment of 5s. a week should continue to be paid for the first child because, under the present wage- fixing system, provision is made for the first child. It is in respect of the second and subsequent children that additional endowment should be paid. Therefore, we consider that child endowment at the rate of £1 a week should be payable for the second, third and fourth children, £1 2s. 6d. for the fifth child, £1 5s. for the sixth child, and so on up to £2 a week for the tenth child. By this means, the income of family men would be put on a firm basis. It has been estimated that such a scheme could cost in the neighbourhood of £41,000,000. Government senators might ask, " Where is the money coming from? " I remind them that, only a few months ago, the Government increased its revenue by £115,000,000 a year by means of what was called the little budget. The additional revenue needed was found within a very short time. A further amount of revenue for the worthwhile objective that I have mentioned could just as easily be obtained.

Figures in relation to pensions are reaching astronomical proportions. I think that it is time that the Government introduced a national insurance scheme, which would enable it to say to the people, " When you reach the age of retirement, you will be entitled to a certain pension as a right ". Of course, I do not say that the pensioners of to-day are not entitled to the pensions that they receive. They have done a great deal to assist the development of Australia.

In order to provide further assistance for the family man, a system of savings certificates at attractive rates of interest, and perhaps tax free for the first £1,000, should be introduced. These certificates would be redeemable on marriage. By this means, young people would be able to acquire homes. Due to the restriction of credit, young married couples at present have great difficulty in obtaining housing loans. In addition, the Government should institute a system of marriage loans for ten-year terms, at low rates of interest, the capital sum owing to be progressively reduced on the birth of each child. Of course, this scheme has been advocated before. I am convinced that its introduction would encourage family life. As we all know, our own Australian children are our best immigrants.

I come now to the financial situation. The- economy of this country is in a delicate state and this budget does nothing to improve it. I presume it is intended to be merely a holding budget. No concrete steps to overcome the inflationary pressures that are at present at work in this country have been proposed. The Government seems to be afraid to control prices or to tax excess profits. Its failure to deal with the hire-purchase octopus has added to the inflationary trend. Money that should be channelled into loans for public works is finding its way into the hire-purchase companies. Why should not the Commonwealth Bank be permitted to bring reasonable rates of interest into this field of finance? If it were permitted to do so, quite a lot of the money that is at present flowing into the hire-purchase companies would be invested in government loans.

Sales taxation has been a bugbear for a great number of years. In my opinion, sales tax should not be imposed on foodstuffs or on domestic appliances. By foodstuffs, I mean scones, cakes and so on. I cannot see why sales tax should be imposed on such commodities. As far as domestic appliances are concerned, I consider that items such as refrigerators should be free of sales tax, bearing in mind our climatic conditions. In most parts of Australia, although perhaps not so much in Tasmania, a refrigerator is an absolute necessity in a home. I consider that the imposition of sales tax on foodstuffs and domestic appliances hinders the family man.
The only equitable means of gaining revenue with which to implement my suggestions is by income taxation.

I should like now to say a few words on defence. It is very pleasing to note that the Government has not been stampeded into reducing the defence vote. In view of the world situation to-day, our defences must be maintained at the highest standard possible consistent with the amount of money that is available for the purpose, because any show of weakness might be the sign for our enemies to step in. Honorable senators have seen what has recently happened in the Middle East. The British Government showed weakness by transferring troops from the Suez Canal zone to Cyprus. In consequence, there has been more trouble in Cyprus than there would have been if the troops had been left in the Canal zone. The safety and security of Australia are bound up in our defence strategy and our foreign policy, under which Australia must maintain the closest possible co-operation with the United States of America. America is the only country that can help us to any extent in any future war, and we should do nothing now to hamper that country's strategy of confining the menace of communism as much as possible to countries within Asia. If Australia does not play its part in that defence strategy, we can abandon all hope for the future. We must agree with the American outlook and do all we can to ensure that red China shall not be recognized by this or any other government in Australia.

It is pleasing to note that there has been very little reduction in the provision for immigration, although, no doubt, pressure has been brought to bear upon the Government to cut down in this direction. It would be foolish to reduce our immigration programme. We urgently need to increase our population for the future progress and defence of Australia. We all know just how much New Australians have done in our factories and on our farms. If Australia is to progress and be adequately defended, it is essential that we maintain our immigration programme. I hope that it will not be long before the Government returns to the quotas it set last year, or to even higher figures. We depend on these people to make Australia the country we want it to be. The Government is also to be congratulated upon realizing the great disparity between the numbers of immigrants of the different sexes and upon taking steps to overcome that difficulty. The important thing to watch now is that we bring in immigrants in the correct categories. At the moment, because of lower intake, we rely on a system of selection. In those circumstances all steps should be taken to ensure that only immigrants in the correct categories shall be brought to this country. We need rural workers and specialized skilled labourers. Specialists are our most urgent need at the moment.

There is also dire need for more housing in Australia. The Government has a responsibility in this respect because, under its immigration scheme which I have praised, it is bringing a great number of people to this country. Those people need homes and as the Government is responsible for immigration it must also bear some responsibility for housing. It controls the purse at the moment and if it is not satisfied that the States are expending wisely the money it has been making available to them for housing, it should take steps to ensure that they do so.

This budget has certain good points which I have mentioned. Its great weakness is its failure to recognize the right of our pensioners to a higher standard of living. Again, I utter the warning that this budget could be defeated on that score alone. I, therefore, advise the Government to look at its budget proposals with a view to changing its attitude towards the needy people in the community. If it does that, I am confident that the pensioners will , realize that the Government is prepared to do something for their benefit. I sincerely trust that the Government will take another look at the budget and do what 1 have asked for the benefit of those people who are under-privileged.

talk.start.para: - I rise to support my leader, Senator McKenna, in his motion of censure of the Government for its present budget. This budget has so many defects that it is rather difficult to know exactly where to begin criticizing it; but before criticizing it At all, I point out that we can see a glimmer of hope, perhaps some reason to believe that the Government is prepared to do something to ameliorate conditions in the social services field, limited though the improvements might be. I regret very much the fact that the Government has not seen fit to increase age and invalid pensions although it is deserving of some congratulation for at least being prepared to make some small allowance to widows with dependent children and to invalid pensioners who have more than one dependent -child. For years now, I have been pressing for some recognition of the widow pensioner who has family responsibilities. In May of last year I moved the adjournment «of the Senate in an endeavour to get something done for this section of the community. Small though the proposed tn- crease in the pension may be, at least it is recognition of a principle for which we have fought over the years. We are grateful for the recognition of that principle, out, at the same time, it is still essential to criticize the Government's lack of consideration for pensioners generally in this budget.

speech.para: I agree that the pensioners should not be made a party political football. They are a very important section of our community. They have helped to build up the country. They have reached the eventide of life and now deserve from the community something better than being required to exist on the small income of £4 a week. It is all very well for the Government to talk about other income that they may have, or the house which they may own or any other improvements of their conditions which it may have effected. All that does not in any way help the basic pensioner who has nothing but his pension upon which to exist.

When Senator Cole spoke of the custom in Formosa of young people looking after their aged parents, I was wondering what happens to the spinster in that country. Their future looks pretty black, but reverting to the serious side of this matter, I remind honorable senators that the idea that the aged should be cared for by the young presupposes that the younger persons in the community have sufficient for their own needs. That is far from the truth to-day.

This budget has done very little indeed to assist the average family man in his struggle to maintain his family adequately without having the added responsibility of his aged parents, no matter how well disposed to assist them he might be. It does not relieve the community of its responsibility. Although it is true that the Government has done much towards encouraging the building of homes for the aged by responsible bodies, that again only touches the fringe of this very serious problem, because Australia is a country in which the proportion of the aged to the young is increasing considerably. This problem is growing in importance each year. We must examine seriously all the conditions of our aged people, including the conditions of employment and sustenance, if we are going to have some sort of national policy towards them. That does not relieve us of the immediate necessity of seeing that those people are adequately fed, housed and clothed.

We all know, from our day-to-day experiences, of the tragedies which beset those who have nothing but their pensions, and of the sufferings they undergo. We know of their privations and of the tragic deaths which come to them as a result' of their need in this land of plenty. It is all very well for us to make contributions to the needy peoples of Asiatic countries. Through this budget, no less than £3,500,000 will be dispensed in that way in aid through the Colombo plan and other agencies to the Asiatic countries. But surely we also have a big responsibility, and a prior responsibility, to the people of Australia, and particularly to those who have no one but the Government to ensure their subsistence because of factors which, throughout their lives, have prevented them from making provision for their old age.

We also have superannuated persons who have made contributions from their salaries during their working years, only to find that they are prevented by the means test from getting the full pension. In that direction, thrift is not encouraged by the Government. No relief is afforded them in this budget. They will suffer severely again unless a supplementary budget is brought down very shortly to assist them to make ends meet.

This has been a particularly severe winter on very old people, and if the Government cannot see its way clear to do something to increase the rate for those who have just begun to receive a pension, I enter a plea for the older persons among the age pensioners. I refer to those who are more than 70 or 75 years. Their need is the greatest. Their overcoats are worn out, but they cannot renew them. They are forced to go to public charities for clothing because prices are too high for them to be able to buy new clothes. It is years since many widows and aged have been able to go into a shop and buy anything new for themselves. We have to look at this problem realistically, and try to place ourselves in the same position as the pensioners, if we would realize the tremendous difficulty they have in trying to feed and clothe themselves on £4 a week.

What is the use of budgeting for a surplus of £108,000,000 if, in getting that surplus, so many persons who have helped to build this nation are to be driven to the depths of despair because their basic needs cannot be met by small pensions? The invalid pensioner who does not happen to have dependent children will be no better off. Only those who have two children dependent upon them, and under the age of sixteen, will receive additional benefits. There are not many people in that category, and what appears to be a fine gesture proves to be one that costs the least. I am glad that the gesture has been made, but I wish it were more generous.

In the case of child endowment, again there has been no increase since 1948 except that the first child is now endowed. I take full responsibility for the fact that the previous Labour Government did not endow the first child. I know that criticism will be levelled at us, but we did increase endowment on the second and subsequent children to 10s. a week in 1948, and the figure has remained unchanged ever since. If child endowment is taken in conjunction with the basic wage, which I use only as a yardstick and not as a definite guide, it will be found that the 10s. that was given in 1948 would have a value of £1 2s. 5d. to-day. That is not my estimate; it comes from the Government Statistician. In order to maintain the 1948 level in the field of child endowment, the payment should be at least £1 2s. 5d. for the second and subsequent children. Parents of large families are not being helped by this budget. The value of the child endowment they are receiving has so dwindled away that it is less than half what it was previously. As no increase has been given, parents are suffering the same disabilities as pensioners, and the budget is due for the same criticism as that levelled at its predecessor last year.

Unemployment and sickness benefits are becoming increasingly important because of the allied problem of unemployment. During the last sessional period, I referred to unemployment in Western Australia. I was told by the Minister for National Development (Senator Spooner) that the figures I cited were grossly exaggerated, and that I was trying to get political kudos from them. No one wants to get political kudos out of the sufferings of other people. I was quoting facts as I knew them. During the parliamentary recess, I had occasion to investigate this matter because of the increasing number of unemployed who were coming not only to my office, but also to my home, and who were absolutely desperate. It is no exaggeration to say that things have not been so bad in that field since the middle 1930's. On a Monday or Tuesday morning any one who goes through the streets of Perth will see queues of people waiting in Queen-street, near the unemployment office. Those queues stretch down to William-street for two or three blocks, and the people wait to register for the unemployment benefit or to inquire whether any work is available for them. 1 have been informed that some men have been told that it is now a waste of time for them to go to the employment office in search of a job, that they should stay at home where they will be informed by letter or telegram if anything turns up. But I believe that, like Micawber's, their wait will be a long one.

The unemployment benefit has not been increased under this budget, but the increased sum has not the same monetary value as it had when this Government assumed office. lt is becoming increasingly difficult for a man to maintain himself on the unemployment benefit in sufficient decency or dignity to enable him to continue the quest for employment. It is all very well for the Government to say, for example, " We have twenty vacancies for employment but only five or six applicants ". If the twenty vacancies are for nurses, and the five or six applicants for work are navvies, the vacancies are of no use to them. That sort of thing has been stressed by the Opposition, but the proportionate number of vacancies and applications for employment have not been explained or clarified by the Government. We should be told of the kinds of vacancies that exist and the kinds of jobs that people are looking for. Men have come to my office who have been desperate to take any sort of work anywhere, and I have been told by the employing authorities that men over 40 have no prospect of getting work. We have recently been talking about age pensions being payable at the age of 65, but what are we to do about men who cannot get work after they reach the ase of 40 years? What is to happen to them in the intervening 25 years? I suggest that that could become a desperate problem.

Under the budget no increase will be made in the amount of the unemployment and sickness benefit. Now I come to maternity benefits. Payments in respect of maternity have not been increased since the last Labour Government left office. They are exactly the same as they were during the years of World War IT., although the expenses connected with the birth of a child have increased enormously. Hospital charges have skyrocketed, and although various hospital benefits and payments are made available through health and hospital societies, at the same time the actual maternity allowance to the mother herself to help her get the few extra things she needs, or to help her with assistance in the home, has not been increased during the seven years that this Government has been in office. The maternity allowance is very important to the mothers of Australa.' We talk about the young Australian being the best immigrant, but we do nothing to help him arrive here by increasing the payment to the mother at the time of the birth of her child. If the maternity allowance had been increased in the same proportion as other charges have been increased over the last seven years, the £15 payable in respect of the first child would now be £33 12s. 5d., the £ 1 6 payable in respect of the second child would be £35 17s. 3d. and the £17 10s. payable in respect of the third and subsequent children would be £39 4s. 6d. So, honorable senators will see that the more children a mother has the worse off she is financially.

Another rather sad social benefit, the funeral benefit payable in respect of pensioners, remains at the sum of £ 1 0 although the cost of dying is getting almost as high as the cost of living. That allowance should be reviewed and adjusted. The only bright spot in all the budget papers is the recognition of the needs of the widow with dependant children, although what the Government has done is still far from the programme that the Opposition set before the Senate last year. A mother with two dependent children will get an income of £4 15s. plus the 15s. child endowment, and so she will still have to exist and bring up her children on a little more than one-third of the basic wage. She would have to be a magician to do that. If she does not get some more recognition by governments in this world, let us hope that she will get something in the hereafter. Otherwise, all our philosophy and striving will have been in vain. These widows have a terrific job to live and bring up their children in a decent way in order to make them good citizens. It is all to the good to bring immigrants from overseas to this country, but we must face up to the duties that we owe to our own citizens.

Other charges imposed in this budget militate against the happiness and welfare of the average Australian family. For example, postal charges have been increased. It is not the additional halfpenny charged on a letter that will make a great deal of difference to people; but telegraph and telephone rates also have been increased. The biggest slug of all is the increase in radio listeners' licence-fees. It is too bad to put up a charge by 37i per cent, and to try to get away with that without a word being said about it in Parliament. The radio listener's licence-fee has been increased to £2 15s.

talk.start.para: - It is the cheapest item that we have.

- It may suit honorable senators to pay such a high licence-fee, or a person who can afford to have half a dozen radio sets and pay the one fee for them all, but it is a heavy impost on a man with a family who is perhaps struggling to pay off his radio set. It might not be too much for an honorable senator to pay, because it represents perhaps only one day's expenses while living in Canberra; but it means a lot to the family man when it is added to other increased charges, including medical and hospital benefit fees. All these charges are really taxes, although they are not recognized as such. I strongly censure the Government for having increased the radio listener's licence-fee by 37£ per cent. It is iniquitous and should be reconsidered. Senators from Western Australia naturally regret that the Government has not paid greater regard to the pleas which have been made from representatives of all parties in this House for greater recognition of the disabilities of settlers in the outback portions of our State, the Northern Territory and Queensland. Much greater rebates in taxation should have been allowed than the paltry sums granted in the budget. Senator Scott might notice that we consider that the people who go into the northern areas of Australia, invest their capital and spend their lives doing what they can to develop and defend these outback parts of the continent, should be given a much greater incentive to do so than the very small taxation remission which has been provided in the budget.

speech.para: The budget could be criticized on many points, and it has been very difficult, within the space of half an hour, to cover all the ground I should like. I hope that the Government will re-examine its social services programme. Any government which takes more notice of the amount of gold in its bank vaults than of the happiness of the people is heading for a downfall, and the sooner this Government falls the better it will be for the nation.

talk.start.para: . - I support the budget, and I shall endeavour to dispel the gloom which has been cast by the speeches of members of the official Opposition. I shall begin by referring to a statement made by Mr. W. S. Robinson, one of the great elder men of Australia. This gentleman has had a long, career in Australia. He was adviser to the Right Honorable W. M. Hughes from 1915 to 1920, and during World War II. was adviser to the Right Honorable John Curtin, the Right Honorable J. B. Chifley and the Right Honorable H. V. Evatt. In the concluding paragraph of a letter which appeared in most of the newspapers throughout Australia recently, he wrote -

quote.para: I know of no country offering greater opportunities to those prepared to assist in her development. No country stands to benefit more than Australia from the discoveries of science. Her future will be great.

speech.para: Since 1949, the population of Australia hasrisen from fewer than 8,000,000 to approximately 9,500,000 and there has been a migration intake of approximately 1,000,000. The national income is at present at an all-time record. In the few years that this Government has been in office it has risen from £2,285,000,000 to- £4,312,000,000. There are vast national development projects under way, such as the Snowy Mountains Hydro-electric scheme, an agricultural revolution is in progress in many parts of Australia as a result of the advent of trace elements, and pastures over large areas have been improved. There have been great mineral finds in the Northern Territory and Queensland, and within the last few days we have learned of the discovery of a large deposit of bauxite which will lay the foundation for the extension of our aluminium industry.

In the last few years, Australia has achieved great status and is now playing a very important part in international affairs. Possibly at this minute the Prime Minister (Mr. Menzies) is undertaking one of the greatest assignments that has ever been given to a human being in this twentieth century, the negotiation of a settlement of the dispute with Egypt over the control of the Suez Canal.

Australia is a truly great country, but, after listening during the last two or three hours to the speeches of honorable senators opposite, .one could have gained the impression that they are living in another age and are not facing the great challenge that now confronts us. The problem is to strike a balance between the long-term objectives of development and population growth, and the more immediate requirements of preserving the prosperity and stability of this growing community. Of course, there is the danger of " boom and bust ", which must be watched. I propose to discuss some matters which I consider of greatest importance. Some honorable senators opposite have said that this is a disastrous budget, and that was the implication in the speech of the Leader of the Opposition (Senator McKenna). However, honorable senators may be interested to know how the commercial community has reacted to the budget. One would think that if it were disastrous, and would result in increased costs which the Leader of . the Opposition suggested would have a momentous effect on our economy, there would have been a certain amount of panic on the stock exchange, but the very reverse has occurred. The bond market - that is, the market for Australian Government securities - has firmed day by day since the budget was brought down. The share price index figures during the last seven days have also been a revelation. Before the budget was delivered the index figure for bank shares was 169.08, but to-day it is 170.72. The figure for retail stores a week ago was 237.70, but now it is 243.28. Industrial shares have risen to almost the same extent. There has been a considerable firming, and even an increase of confidence since the budget was read. The preservation of the sound and stable economic conditions which the Government set its mind to achieve has been received as an accomplished fact.

In order to increase development, it is necessary that Australia should encourage the investment of more public and private overseas capital. We want capital to come here and remain, and to leave its earnings here for re-investment. It is encouraging to know that recently, when the Prime Minister was in the United States of America, he was able to make arrangements for a further loan from the International Bank. The Opposition begins to moan when I refer to the International Bank, but I remind them that the loans obtained from that source have been of the greatest assistance to Australia during the last five years. The whole point is that every time the confirmation of one of these loans comes before this chamber Opposition senators to a man vote against it. Thereby, they have voted against the introduction into this country of beneficial earth-moving equipment, equipment for coal-fields in South Australia, and equipment for the dieselization of the east-west railway and for other important developmental projects. By their vote every honorable senator opposite has voted against the introduction of these beneficial things, and it is evident, as a result of their grizzling this evening, that when such a loan comes before the Senate for ratification they will vote against it. They are now revealing their attitude in respect of the future development of Australia. Do they want the money for this development to be taken out of the peoples' pockets by taxation, or are they prepared to support this Government in its approach to the International Bank for this accommodation? I repeat that the help this country has received from the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development has been invaluable, and I am proud of the fact that the Prime Minister (Mr. Menzies) has been able to negotiate a further loan. I believe that certain eminent gentlemen associated with the bank are in Australia at the present time.

Let me now say a word or two about the budget itself. In effect, it is a document to provide £1,121,000,000 to meet expenditure. Defence will take £190,000,000, approximately the same as last year; repatriation services, £123,000,000; social services, £222,000,000, a rise of 5 per cent.; and payments to the States, £243,000,000, a rise of 10 per cent. These vast sums of money can be raised either by taxation, by loan or by both. It is of great importance that the Senate should study the subject of loan raisings within Australia to see if there are ways in which we can improve our approach to the public in that sphere. It should be remembered that if the money is not raised by loan, it will be raised by taxation; and it has always been the aim of this Government to reduce taxation rather than to raise it. It has also been the policy of this Government to pay for capital works out of loan moneys, but the Government has virtually vacated the loan-raising field for its own works in favour of the States. It has underwritten the States' loan programme to a very large extent, and the gap which has to be bridged by the shortfall in loan raisings is being made up. by taxation. The support given to the States has been quite considerable over the last three years. In addition to normal taxation re-imbursements it has reached the extent of £91,000,000. That support has had to be given because of the short-fall of loan raisings. I propose to develop further the subject of loan raisings. I ask for leave to continue my remarks at a later date.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.
